noemo	"My little old man and I fell out, How shall we bring this matter about?
noemo	Bring it about as well as you can, And get you gone, you little old man!"
noemo	"You could squeeze in, through that little round hole," said Goody Tiptoes.
noemo	"Yes, I could," said the Chipmunk, "but my husband, Chippy Hackee, bites!"
noemo	Down below there was a noise of cracking nuts and nibbling; and then the fat squirrel voice and the thin squirrel voice sang--
noemo	"For the diddlum day Day diddle durn di!
noemo	Day diddle diddle dum day!"
noemo	Then Goody peeped in at the hole, and called down--"Timmy Tiptoes!
anger	Oh fie, Timmy Tiptoes!"
noemo	And Timmy replied, "Is that you, Goody Tiptoes?
noemo	Why, certainly!"
joy	He came up and kissed Goody through the hole; but he was so fat that he could not get out.
joy	Chippy Hackee was not too fat, but he did not want to come; he stayed down below and chuckled.
noemo	And so it went on for a fort- night; till a big wind blew off the top of the tree, and opened up the hole and let in the rain.
noemo	Then Timmy Tiptoes came out, and went home with an umbrella.
noemo	But Chippy Hackee continued to camp out for another week, although it was uncomfortable.
noemo	At last a large bear came walking through the wood.
noemo	Perhaps he also was looking for nuts; he seemed to be sniffing around.
fear	Chippy Hackee went home in a hurry!
sadness	And when Chippy Hackee got home, he found he had caught a cold in his head; and he was more uncomfortable still.
noemo	And now Timmy and Goody Tiptoes keep their nut store fastened up with a little padlock.
noemo	And whenever that little bird sees the Chipmunks, he sings--"Who's-been-digging- up MY-nuts?
noemo	Who's been dig- ging-up MY-nuts?"
noemo	But nobody ever answers!
noemo	Once upon a time there were four little Rabbits, and their names were-- Flopsy, Mopsy, Cotton-tail, and Peter.
noemo	They lived with their Mother in a sand-bank, underneath the root of a very big fir-tree.
noemo	"Now, my dears," said old Mrs. Rabbit one morning, "you may go into the fields or down the lane, but don't go into Mr. McGregor's garden: your Father had an accident there; he was put in a pie by Mrs. McGregor."
noemo	"Now run along, and don't get into mischief.
noemo	I am going out."
noemo	Then old Mrs. Rabbit took a basket and her umbrella, and went through the wood to the baker's.
noemo	She bought a loaf of brown bread and five currant buns.
noemo	Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail, who were good little bunnies, went down the lane to gather blackberries;
noemo	But Peter, who was very naughty, ran straight away to Mr. McGregor's garden, and squeezed under the gate!
noemo	First he ate some lettuces and some French beans; and then he ate some radishes;
sadness	And then, feeling rather sick, he went to look for some parsley.
surprise	But round the end of a cucumber frame, whom should he meet but Mr. McGregor!
anger	Mr. McGregor was on his hands and knees planting out young cabbages, but he jumped up and ran after Peter, waving a rake and calling out, "Stop thief."
fear	Peter was most dreadfully frightened; he rushed all over the garden, for he had forgotten the way back to the gate.
noemo	He lost one of his shoes among the cabbages, and the other shoe amongst the potatoes.
noemo	After losing them, he ran on four legs and went faster, so that I think he might have got away altogether if he had not unfortunately run into a gooseberry net, and got caught by the large buttons on his jacket.
noemo	It was a blue jacket with brass buttons, quite new.
sadness	Peter gave himself up for lost, and shed big tears; but his sobs were overheard by some friendly sparrows, who flew to him in great excitement, and implored him to exert himself.
noemo	Mr. McGregor came up with a sieve, which he intended to pop upon the top of Peter; but Peter wriggled out just in time, leaving his jacket behind him.
noemo	And rushed into the toolshed, and jumped into a can.
noemo	It would have been a beautiful thing to hide in, if it had not had so much water in it.
noemo	Mr. McGregor was quite sure that Peter was somewhere in the toolshed, perhaps hidden underneath a flower- pot.
noemo	He began to turn them over carefully, looking under each.
noemo	Presently Peter sneezed-- "Kertyschoo!"
noemo	Mr. McGregor was after him in no time,
noemo	And tried to put his foot upon Peter, who jumped out of a window, upsetting three plants.
noemo	The window was too small for Mr. McGregor, and he was tired of running after Peter.
noemo	He went back to his work.
fear	Peter sat down to rest; he was out of breath and trembling with fright, and he had not the least idea which way to go.
noemo	Also he was very damp with sitting in that can.
noemo	After a time he began to wander about, going lippity--lippity--not very fast, and looking all around.
noemo	He found a door in a wall; but it was locked, and there was no room for a fat little rabbit to squeeze underneath.
noemo	An old mouse was running in and out over the stone doorstep, carrying peas and beans to her family in the wood.
noemo	Peter asked her the way to the gate, but she had such a large pea in her mouth that she could not answer.
noemo	She only shook her head at him.
sadness	Peter began to cry.
sadness	Then he tried to find his way straight across the garden, but he became more and more puzzled.
noemo	Presently, he came to a pond where Mr. McGregor filled his water-cans.
noemo	A white cat was staring at some goldfish; she sat very, very still, but now and then the tip of her tail twitched as if it were alive.
noemo	Peter thought it best to go away without speaking to her; he has heard about cats from his cousin, little Benjamin Bunny.
surprise	He went back towards the toolshed, but suddenly, quite close to him, he heard the noise of a hoe-- scr-r-ritch, scratch, scratch, scritch.
fear	Peter scuttered underneath the bushes.
noemo	But presently, as nothing happened, he came out, and climbed upon a wheelbarrow, and peeped over.
noemo	The first thing he saw was Mr. McGregor hoeing onions.
noemo	His back was turned towards Peter, and beyond him was the gate!
noemo	Peter got down very quietly off the wheelbarrow, and started running as fast as he could go, along a straight walk behind some black-currant bushes.
noemo	Mr. McGregor caught sight of him at the corner, but Peter did not care.
surprise	He slipped underneath the gate, and was safe at last in the wood outside the garden.
noemo	Mr. McGregor hung up the little jacket and the shoes for a scare-crow to frighten the blackbirds.
noemo	Peter never stopped running or looked behind him till he got home to the big fir-tree.
noemo	He was so tired that he flopped down upon the nice soft sand on the floor of the rabbit-hole, and shut his eyes.
noemo	His mother was busy cooking; she wondered what he had done with his clothes.
surprise	It was the second little jacket and pair of shoes that Peter had lost in a fortnight!
sadness	I am sorry to say that Peter was not very well during the evening.
noemo	His mother put him to bed, and made some camomile tea; and she gave a dose of it to Peter!
noemo	"One table-spoonful to be taken at bed-time."
noemo	But Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail had bread and milk and blackberries for supper.
noemo	Pussy-cat sits by the fire--how should she be fair?
noemo	In walks the little dog--says "Pussy are you there?
noemo	How do you do Mistress Pussy?
noemo	Mistress Pussy, how do you do?"
joy	"I thank you kindly, little dog, I fare as well as you!" [Old Rhyme]
noemo	Once upon a time there was a Pussy-cat called Ribby, who invited a little dog called Duchess to tea.
joy	"Come in good time, my dear Duchess," said Ribby's letter, "and we will have something so very nice.
noemo	I am baking it in a pie-dish--a pie-dish with a pink rim.
joy	You never tasted anything so good!
joy	And YOU shall eat it all! _I_ will eat muffins, my dear Duchess!" wrote Ribby.
noemo	"I will come very punctually, my dear Ribby," wrote Duchess; and then at the end she added--"I hope it isn't mouse?"
noemo	And then she thought that did not look quite polite; so she scratched out "isn't mouse" and changed it to "I hope it will be fine," and she gave her letter to the postman.
noemo	But she thought a great deal about Ribby's pie, and she read Ribby's letter over and over again.
fear	"I am dreadfully afraid it WILL be mouse!" said Duchess to herself--"I really couldn't, COULDN'T eat mouse pie.
fear	And I shall have to eat it, because it is a party.
noemo	And MY pie was going to be veal and ham.
noemo	A pink and white pie-dish! and so is mine; just like Ribby's dishes; they were both bought at Tabitha Twitchit's."
noemo	Duchess went into her larder and took the pie off a shelf and looked at it.
joy	"Oh what a good idea!
joy	Why shouldn't I rush along and put my pie into Ribby's oven when Ribby isn't there?"
noemo	Ribby in the meantime had received Duchess's answer, and as soon as she was sure that the little dog would come--she popped HER pie into the oven.
noemo	There were two ovens, one above the other; some other knobs and handles were only ornamental and not intended to open.
noemo	Ribby put the pie into the lower oven; the door was very stiff.
noemo	"The top oven bakes too quickly," said Ribby to herself.
noemo	Ribby put on some coal and swept up the hearth.
noemo	Then she went out with a can to the well, for water to fill up the kettle.
noemo	Then she began to set the room in order, for it was the sitting-room as well as the kitchen.
noemo	When Ribby had laid the table she went out down the field to the farm, to fetch milk and butter.
noemo	When she came back, she peeped into the bottom oven; the pie looked very comfortable.
noemo	Ribby put on her shawl and bonnet and went out again with a basket, to the village shop to buy a packet of tea, a pound of lump sugar, and a pot of marmalade.
noemo	And just at the same time, Duchess came out of HER house, at the other end of the village.
noemo	Ribby met Duchess half-way down the street, also carrying a basket, covered with a cloth.
noemo	They only bowed to one another; they did not speak, because they were going to have a party.
noemo	As soon as Duchess had got round the corner out of sight--she simply ran!
noemo	Straight away to Ribby's house!
joy	Ribby went into the shop and bought what she required, and came out, after a pleasant gossip with Cousin Tabitha Twitchit.
noemo	Ribby went on to Timothy Baker's and bought the muffins.
noemo	Then she went home.
noemo	There seemed to be a sort of scuffling noise in the back passage, as she was coming in at the front door.
noemo	But there was nobody there.
noemo	Duchess in the meantime, had slipped out at the back door.
surprise	"It is a very odd thing that Ribby's pie was NOT in the oven when I put mine in!
surprise	And I can't find it anywhere; I have looked all over the house.
noemo	I put MY pie into a nice hot oven at the top.
noemo	I could not turn any of the other handles; I think that they are all shams," said Duchess, "but I wish I could have removed the pie made of mouse!
noemo	I cannot think what she has done with it?
surprise	I heard Ribby coming and I had to run out by the back door!"
noemo	Duchess went home and brushed her beautiful black coat; and then she picked a bunch of flowers in her garden as a present for Ribby; and passed the time until the clock struck four.
noemo	Ribby--having assured herself by careful search that there was really no one hiding in the cupboard or in the larder--went upstairs to change her dress.
noemo	She came downstairs again, and made the tea, and put the teapot on the hob.
noemo	She peeped again into the BOTTOM oven, the pie had become a lovely brown, and it was steaming hot.
noemo	She sat down before the fire to wait for the little dog.
joy	"I am glad I used the BOTTOM oven," said Ribby, "the top one would certainly have been very much too hot."
noemo	Very punctually at four o'clock, Duchess started to go to the party.
noemo	At a quarter past four to the minute, there came a most genteel little tap-tappity.
noemo	"Is Mrs. Ribston at home?" inquired Duchess in the porch.
joy	"Come in! and how do you do, my dear Duchess?" cried Ribby.
joy	"I hope I see you well?"
joy	"Quite well, I thank you, and how do YOU do, my dear Ribby?" said Duchess.
joy	"I've brought you some flowers; what a delicious smell of pie!"
joy	"Oh, what lovely flowers!
joy	Yes, it is mouse and bacon!"
noemo	"I think it wants another five minutes," said Ribby.
noemo	"Just a shade longer; I will pour out the tea, while we wait.
noemo	Do you take sugar, my dear Duchess?"
joy	"Oh yes, please! my dear Ribby; and may I have a lump upon my nose?"
joy	"With pleasure, my dear Duchess."
noemo	Duchess sat up with the sugar on her nose and sniffed--
joy	"How good that pie smells!
joy	I do love veal and ham--I mean to say mouse and bacon--"
noemo	She dropped the sugar in confusion, and had to go hunting under the tea- table, so did not see which oven Ribby opened in order to get out the pie.
noemo	Ribby set the pie upon the table; there was a very savoury smell.
noemo	Duchess came out from under the table-cloth munching sugar, and sat up on a chair.
noemo	"I will first cut the pie for you; I am going to have muffin and marmalade," said Ribby.
noemo	"I think"--(thought Duchess to herself)--"I THINK it would be wiser if I helped myself to pie; though Ribby did not seem to notice anything when she was cutting it.
noemo	What very small fine pieces it has cooked into!
noemo	I did not remember that I had minced it up so fine; I suppose this is a quicker oven than my own."
noemo	The pie-dish was emptying rapidly!
noemo	Duchess had had four helps already, and was fumbling with the spoon.
joy	"A little more bacon, my dear Duchess?" said Ribby.
joy	"Thank you, my dear Ribby; I was only feeling for the patty-pan."
noemo	"The patty-pan? my dear Duchess?"
noemo	"The patty pan that held up the pie-crust," said Duchess, blushing under her black coat.
noemo	"Oh, I didn't put one in, my dear Duchess," said Ribby; "I don't think that it is necessary in pies made of mouse."
surprise	"There isn't a patty-pan," said Ribby, looking perplexed.
surprise	"Yes, indeed, my dear Ribby; where can it have gone to?" said Duchess.
fear	Duchess looked very much alarmed, and continued to scoop the inside of the pie-dish.
noemo	"I have only four patty-pans, and they are all in the cupboard."
fear	Oh, my dear Ribby, I do feel so ill!"
noemo	"It is impossible, my dear Duchess; there was not a patty-pan."
fear	"Yes there WAS, my dear Ribby, I am sure I have swallowed it!"
noemo	"Let me prop you up with a pillow, my dear Duchess; where do you think you feel it?"
fear	"Oh I do feel so ill ALL OVER me, my dear Ribby."
noemo	"Shall I run for the doctor?"
noemo	"Oh yes, yes! fetch Dr. Maggotty, my dear Ribby: he is a Pie himself, he will certainly understand."
noemo	Ribby settled Duchess in an armchair before the fire, and went out and hurried to the village to look for the doctor.
noemo	She found him at the smithy.
noemo	Ribby explained that her guest had swallowed a patty-pan.
fear	Dr. Maggotty hopped so fast that Ribby had to run.
noemo	It was most conspicuous.
noemo	All the village could see that Ribby was fetching the doctor.
fear	But while Ribby had been hunting for the doctor--a curious thing had happened to Duchess, who had been left by herself, sitting before the fire, sighing and groaning and feeling very unhappy.
surprise	"How COULD I have swallowed it! such a large thing as a patty-pan!"
sadness	She sat down again, and stared mournfully at the grate.
noemo	The fire crackled and danced, and something sizz-z-zled!
surprise	Duchess started!
surprise	She opened the door of the TOP oven;--out came a rich steamy flavour of veal and ham, and there stood a fine brown pie,-- and through a hole in the top of the pie-crust there was a glimpse of a little tin patty-pan!
joy	Duchess drew a long breath--
surprise	"Then I must have been eating MOUSE!
noemo	. . .
noemo	. . .
noemo	But perhaps I should feel worse if I had really swallowed a patty-pan!"
fear	Duchess reflected--"What a very awkward thing to have to explain to Ribby!
noemo	I think I will put MY pie in the back-yard and say nothing about it.
noemo	When I go home, I will run round and take it away."
noemo	She put it outside the back-door, and sat down again by the fire, and shut her eyes; when Ribby arrived with the doctor, she seemed fast asleep.
joy	"I am feeling very much better," said Duchess, waking up with a jump.
joy	"I am truly glad to hear it!
noemo	He has brought you a pill, my dear Duchess!"
noemo	"I think I should feel QUITE well if he only felt my pulse," said Duchess, backing away from the magpie, who sidled up with something in his beak.
noemo	"It is only a bread pill, you had much better take it; drink a little milk, my dear Duchess!"
noemo	"I am feeling very much better, my dear Ribby," said Duchess.
noemo	"Do you not think that I had better go home before it gets dark?"
noemo	"Perhaps it might be wise, my dear Duchess."
joy	Ribby and Duchess said good-bye affectionately, and Duchess started home.
noemo	Half-way up the lane she stopped and looked back; Ribby had gone in and shut her door.
noemo	Duchess slipped through the fence, and ran round to the back of Ribby's house, and peeped into the yard.
noemo	Upon the roof of the pig-stye sat Dr. Maggotty and three jackdaws.
noemo	The jackdaws were eating piecrust, and the magpie was drinking gravy out of a patty-pan.
surprise	When Ribby came out for a pailful of water to wash up the tea-things, she found a pink and white pie-dish lying smashed in the middle of the yard.
surprise	Ribby stared with amazement-- "Did you ever see the like! so there really WAS a patty-pan?
noemo	. . .
surprise	But MY patty-pans are all in the kitchen cupboard.
surprise	Well I never did!
noemo	. . .
noemo	Next time I want to give a party--I will invite Cousin Tabitha Twitchit!"
noemo	Once upon a time there was a frog called Mr. Jeremy Fisher; he lived in a little damp house amongst the buttercups at the edge of a pond.
noemo	The water was all slippy-sloppy in the larder and in the back passage.
joy	But Mr. Jeremy liked getting his feet wet; nobody ever scolded him, and he never caught a cold!
joy	He was quite pleased when he looked out and saw large drops of rain, splashing in the pond--
noemo	"I will get some worms and go fishing and catch a dish of minnows for my dinner," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
noemo	"If I catch more than five fish, I will invite my friends Mr. Alderman Ptolemy Tortoise and Sir Isaac Newton.
noemo	The Alderman, however, eats salad."
noemo	Mr. Jeremy put on a mackintosh, and a pair of shiny galoshes; he took his rod and basket, and set off with enormous hops to the place where he kept his boat.
noemo	The boat was round and green, and very like the other lily-leaves.
noemo	It was tied to a water-plant in the middle of the pond.
noemo	Mr. Jeremy took a reed pole, and pushed the boat out into open water.
noemo	"I know a good place for minnows," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
noemo	Mr. Jeremy stuck his pole into the mud and fastened the boat to it.
noemo	Then he settled himself cross- legged and arranged his fishing tackle.
noemo	He had the dearest little red float.
noemo	His rod was a tough stalk of grass, his line was a fine long white horse-hair, and he tied a little wriggling worm at the end.
noemo	The rain trickled down his back, and for nearly an hour he stared at the float.
disgust	"This is getting tiresome, I think I should like some lunch," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
noemo	He punted back again amongst the water-plants, and took some lunch out of his basket.
noemo	"I will eat a butterfly sandwich, and wait till the shower is over," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
noemo	A great big water-beetle came up underneath the lily leaf and tweaked the toe of one of his galoshes.
noemo	Mr. Jeremy crossed his legs up shorter, out of reach, and went on eating his sandwich.
noemo	Once or twice something moved about with a rustle and a splash amongst the rushes at the side of the pond.
fear	"I trust that is not a rat," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher; "I think I had better get away from here."
noemo	Mr. Jeremy shoved the boat out again a little way, and dropped in the bait.
noemo	There was a bite almost directly; the float gave a tremendous bobbit!
surprise	"A minnow! a minnow!
surprise	I have him by the nose!" cried Mr. Jeremy Fisher, jerking up his rod.
surprise	But what a horrible surprise!
noemo	Instead of a smooth fat minnow, Mr. Jeremy landed little Jack Sharp, the stickleback, covered with spines!
noemo	Then he jumped back into the water.
surprise	A great big enormous trout came up--ker-pflop-p-p-p! with a splash-- and it seized Mr. Jeremy with a snap, "Ow!
surprise	Ow!
surprise	Ow!"--and then it turned and dived down to the bottom of the pond!
disgust	But the trout was so displeased with the taste of the mackintosh, that in less than half a minute it spat him out again; and the only thing it swallowed was Mr. Jeremy's galoshes.
noemo	Mr. Jeremy bounced up to the surface of the water, like a cork and the bubbles out of a soda water bottle; and he swam with all his might to the edge of the pond.
fear	He scrambled out on the first bank he came to, and he hopped home across the meadow with his mackintosh all in tatters.
joy	"What a mercy that was not a pike!" said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
noemo	He put some sticking plaster on his fingers, and his friends both came to dinner.
noemo	He could not offer them fish, but he had something else in his larder.
noemo	Sir Isaac Newton wore his black and gold waistcoat.
noemo	And Mr. Alderman Ptolemy Tortoise brought a salad with him in a string bag.
noemo	And instead of a nice dish of minnows, they had a roasted grasshopper with lady-bird sauce, which frogs consider a beautiful treat; but _I_ think it must have been nasty!
noemo	Once upon a time there was an old pig called Aunt Pettitoes.
noemo	She had eight of a family: four little girl pigs, called Cross-patch, Suck-suck, Yock-yock and Spot; and four little boy pigs, called Alexander, Pigling Bland, Chin-Chin and Stumpy.
noemo	Stumpy had had an accident to his tail.
joy	The eight little pigs had very fine appetites--"Yus, yus, yus! they eat and indeed they DO eat!" said Aunt Pettitoes, looking at her family with pride.
fear	Suddenly there were fearful squeals; Alexander had squeezed inside the hoops of the pig trough and stuck.
noemo	Aunt Pettitoes and I dragged him out by the hind legs.
fear	Chin-chin was already in disgrace; it was washing day, and he had eaten a piece of soap.
surprise	And presently in a basket of clean clothes, we found another dirty little pig--"Tchut, tut, tut! whichever is this?" grunted Aunt Pettitoes.
noemo	Now all the pig family are pink, or pink with black spots, but this pig child was smutty black all over; when it had been popped into a tub, it proved to be Yock-yock.
noemo	I went into the garden; there I found Cross-patch and Suck-suck rooting up carrots.
noemo	I whipped them myself and led them out by the ears.
anger	Cross-patch tried to bite me.
noemo	"Aunt Pettitoes, Aunt Pettitoes! you are a worthy person, but your family is not well brought up.
noemo	Every one of them has been in mischief except Spot and Pigling Bland."
noemo	"And they drink bucketfuls of milk; I shall have to get another cow!
noemo	Good little Spot shall stay at home to do the housework; but the others must go.
noemo	Four little boy pigs and four little girl pigs are too many altogether."
sadness	"Yus, yus, yus," said Aunt Pettitoes, "there will be more to eat without them."
noemo	So Chin-chin and Suck-suck went away in a wheel-barrow, and Stumpy, Yock-yock and Cross- patch rode away in a cart.
noemo	And the other two little boy pigs, Pigling Bland and Alexander went to market.
noemo	We brushed their coats, we curled their tails and washed their little faces, and wished them good bye in the yard.
sadness	Aunt Pettitoes wiped her eyes with a large pocket handkerchief, then she wiped Pigling Bland's nose and shed tears; then she wiped Alexander's nose and shed tears; then she passed the handkerchief to Spot.
sadness	Aunt Pettitoes sighed and grunted, and addressed those little pigs as follows--
noemo	"Now Pigling Bland, son Pigling Bland, you must go to market.
noemo	Take your brother Alexander by the hand.
noemo	Mind your Sunday clothes, and remember to blow your nose" --(Aunt Pettitoes passed round the handkerchief again)--"beware of traps, hen roosts, bacon and eggs; always walk upon your hind legs."
sadness	Pigling Bland who was a sedate little pig, looked solemnly at his mother, a tear trickled down his cheek.
joy	Aunt Pettitoes turned to the other--"Now son Alexander take the hand"--"Wee, wee, wee!" giggled Alexander--"take the hand of your brother Pigling Bland, you must go to market.
noemo	Mind--" "Wee, wee, wee!" interrupted Alexander again.
noemo	"You put me out," said Aunt Pettitoes--"Observe signposts and milestones; do not gobble herring bones--" "And remember," said I impressively, "if you once cross the county boundary you cannot come back.
noemo	Alexander, you are not attending.
noemo	Here are two licenses permitting two pigs to go to market in Lancashire.
noemo	Attend Alexander.
noemo	I have had no end of trouble in getting these papers from the policeman."
sadness	Pigling Bland listened gravely; Alexander was hopelessly volatile.
noemo	I pinned the papers, for safety, inside their waistcoat pockets; Aunt Pettitoes gave to each a little bundle, and eight conversation peppermints with appropriate moral sentiments in screws of paper.
noemo	Then they started.
noemo	Pigling Bland and Alexander trotted along steadily for a mile; at least Pigling Bland did.
noemo	Alexander made the road half as long again by skipping from side to side.
joy	He danced about and pinched his brother, singing--
joy	"This pig went to market, this pig stayed at home, "This pig had a bit of meat--
noemo	let's see what they have given US for dinner, Pigling?"
noemo	Pigling Bland and Alexander sat down and untied their bundles.
noemo	Alexander gobbled up his dinner in no time; he had already eaten all his own peppermints--"Give me one of yours, please, Pigling?"
noemo	"But I wish to preserve them for emergencies," said Pigling Bland doubtfully.
joy	Alexander went into squeals of laughter.
anger	Then he pricked Pigling with the pin that had fastened his pig paper; and when Pigling slapped him he dropped the pin, and tried to take Pigling's pin, and the papers got mixed up.
anger	Pigling Bland reproved Alexander.
joy	But presently they made it up again, and trotted away together, singing--
noemo	"Tom, Tom the piper's son, stole a pig and away he ran!
noemo	"But all the tune that he could play, was `Over the hills and far away!'"
noemo	"What's that, young Sirs?
noemo	Stole a pig?
noemo	Where are your licenses?" said the policeman.
noemo	They had nearly run against him round a corner.
noemo	Pigling Bland pulled out his paper; Alexander, after fumbling, handed over something scrumply--
surprise	"To 2 1/2 oz. conversation sweeties at three farthings"--"What's this? this ain't a license?"
fear	Alexander's nose lengthened visibly, he had lost it.
fear	"I had one, indeed I had, Mr. Policeman!"
noemo	"It's not likely they let you start without.
noemo	I am passing the farm.
noemo	You may walk with me."
noemo	"Can I come back too?" inquired Pigling Bland.
noemo	"I see no reason, young Sir; your paper is all right."
fear	Pigling Bland did not like going on alone, and it was beginning to rain.
noemo	But it is unwise to argue with the police; he gave his brother a peppermint, and watched him out of sight.
sadness	To conclude the adventures of Alexander--the policeman sauntered up to the house about tea time, followed by a damp subdued little pig.
noemo	I disposed of Alexander in the neighborhood; he did fairly well when he had settled down.
sadness	Pigling Bland went on alone dejectedly; he came to cross roads and a sign-post--"To Market-town 5 miles," "Over the Hills, 4 miles," "To Pettitoes Farm, 3 miles."
surprise	Pigling Bland was shocked, there was little hope of sleeping in Market Town, and tomorrow was the hiring fair; it was deplorable to think how much time had been wasted by the frivolity of Alexander.
noemo	He glanced wistfully along the road towards the hills, and then set off walking obediently the other way, buttoning up his coat against the rain.
noemo	"I wish I could have a little garden and grow potatoes," said Pigling Bland.
surprise	He put his cold hand in his pocket and felt his paper, he put his other hand in his other pocket and felt another paper--Alexander's!
noemo	He took a wrong turn--several wrong turns, and was quite lost.
noemo	It grew dark, the wind whistled, the trees creaked and groaned.
fear	Pigling Bland became frightened and cried "Wee, wee, wee!
fear	I can't find my way home!"
noemo	After an hour's wandering he got out of the wood; the moon shone through the clouds, and Pigling Bland saw a country that was new to him.
noemo	The road crossed a moor; below was a wide valley with a river twinkling in the moonlight, and beyond --in misty distance--lay the hills.
sadness	He saw a small wooden hut, made his way to it, and crept inside --"I am afraid it IS a hen house, but what can I do?" said Pigling Bland, wet and cold and quite tired out.
joy	"Bacon and eggs, bacon and eggs!" clucked a hen on a perch.
anger	"Trap, trap, trap! cackle, cackle, cackle!" scolded the disturbed cockerel.
joy	"To market, to market! jiggettyjig!" clucked a broody white hen roosting next to him.
fear	Pigling Bland, much alarmed, determined to leave at daybreak.
noemo	In the meantime, he and the hens fell asleep.
noemo	In less than an hour they were all awakened.
noemo	The owner, Mr. Peter Thomas Piperson, came with a lantern and a hamper to catch six fowls to take to market in the morning.
noemo	He grabbed the white hen roosting next to the cock; then his eye fell upon Pigling Bland, squeezed up in a corner.
surprise	He made a singular remark--"Hallo, here's another!" --seized Pigling by the scruff of the neck, and dropped him into the hamper.
noemo	Then he dropped in five more dirty, kicking, cackling hens upon the top of Pigling Bland.
noemo	The hamper containing six fowls and a young pig was no light weight; it was taken down hill, unsteadily, with jerks.
noemo	Pigling, although nearly scratched to pieces, contrived to hide the papers and peppermints inside his clothes.
noemo	At last the hamper was bumped down upon a kitchen floor, the lid was opened, and Pigling was lifted out.
joy	He looked up, blinking, and saw an offensively ugly elderly man, grinning from ear to ear.
noemo	"This one's come of himself, whatever," said Mr. Piperson, turning Pigling's pockets inside out.
noemo	He pushed the hamper into a corner, threw a sack over it to keep the hens quiet, put a pot on the fire, and unlaced his boots.
noemo	Pigling Bland drew forward a coppy stool, and sat on the edge of it, shyly warming his hands.
noemo	Mr. Piperson pulled off a boot and threw it against the wainscot at the further end of the kitchen.
anger	There was a smothered noise--"Shut up!" said Mr. Piperson.
noemo	Pigling Bland warmed his hands, and eyed him.
anger	Mr. Piperson pulled off the other boot and flung it after the first, there was again a curious noise-- "Be quiet, will ye?" said Mr. Piperson.
noemo	Pigling Bland sat on the very edge of the coppy stool.
noemo	Mr. Piperson fetched meal from a chest and made porridge, it seemed to Pigling that something at the further end of the kitchen was taking a suppressed interest in the cooking; but he was too hungry to be troubled by noises.
noemo	Mr. Piperson poured out three platefuls: for himself, for Pigling, and a third-after glaring at Pigling-- he put away with much scuffling, and locked up.
noemo	Pigling Bland ate his supper discreetly.
noemo	After supper Mr. Piperson consulted an almanac, and felt Pigling's ribs; it was too late in the season for curing bacon, and he grudged his meal.
noemo	Besides, the hens had seen this pig.
noemo	He looked at the small remains of a flitch [side of bacon], and then looked undecidedly at Pigling.
noemo	"You may sleep on the rug," said Mr. Peter Thomas Piperson.
noemo	Pigling Bland slept like a top.
noemo	In the morning Mr. Piperson made more porridge; the weather was warmer.
noemo	He looked how much meal was left in the chest, and seemed dissatisfied--"You'll likely be moving on again?" said he to Pigling Bland.
noemo	Before Pigling could reply, a neighbor, who was giving Mr. Piperson and the hens a lift, whistled from the gate.
anger	Mr. Piperson hurried out with the hamper, enjoining Pigling to shut the door behind him and not meddle with nought; or "I'll come back and skin ye!" said Mr. Piperson.
noemo	It crossed Pigling's mind that if HE had asked for a lift, too, he might still have been in time for market.
fear	But he distrusted Peter Thomas.
noemo	After finishing breakfast at his leisure, Pigling had a look round the cottage; everything was locked up.
noemo	He found some potato peelings in a bucket in the back kitchen.
noemo	Pigling ate the peel, and washed up the porridge plates in the bucket.
noemo	He sang while he worked--
noemo	"Tom with his pipe made such a noise, He called up all the girls and boys-- "And they all ran to hear him play, "Over the hills and far away!--"
noemo	Suddenly a little smothered voice chimed in--
noemo	"Over the hills and a great way off, The wind shall blow my top knot off."
surprise	Pigling Bland put down a plate which he was wiping, and listened.
noemo	After a long pause, Pigling went on tiptoe and peeped round the door into the front kitchen; there was nobody there.
noemo	After another pause, Pigling approached the door of the locked cupboard, and snuffed at the keyhole.
noemo	It was quite quiet.
noemo	After another long pause, Pigling pushed a peppermint under the door.
noemo	It was sucked in immediately.
noemo	In the course of the day Pigling pushed in all his remaining six peppermints.
noemo	When Mr. Piperson returned, he found Pigling sitting before the fire; he had brushed up the hearth and put on the pot to boil; the meal was not get-at-able.
noemo	Mr. Piperson was very affable; he slapped Pigling on the back, made lots of porridge and forgot to lock the meal chest.
noemo	He did lock the cupboard door; but without properly shutting it.
noemo	He went to bed early, and told Pigling upon no account to disturb him next day before twelve o'clock.
noemo	Pigling Bland sat by the fire, eating his supper.
noemo	All at once at his elbow, a little voice spoke--"My name is Pig-wig.
noemo	Make me more porridge, please!"
surprise	Pigling Bland jumped, and looked round.
joy	A perfectly lovely little black Berkshire pig stood smiling beside him.
noemo	She had twinkly little screwed up eyes, a double chin, and a short turned up nose.
noemo	She pointed at Pigling's plate; he hastily gave it to her, and fled to the meal chest--"How did you come here?" asked Pigling Bland.
noemo	"Stolen," replied Pig-wig, with her mouth full.
noemo	Pigling helped himself to meal without scruple.
noemo	"What for?"
joy	"Bacon, hams," replied Pig- wig cheerfully.
joy	"I shall after supper," said Pig- wig decidedly.
joy	Pigling Bland made more porridge and watched her shyly.
noemo	She finished a second plate, got up, and looked about her, as though she were going to start.
noemo	"You can't go in the dark," said Pigling Bland.
fear	Pig-wig looked anxious.
noemo	"Do you know your way by day- light?"
noemo	"I know we can see this little white house from the hills across the river.
noemo	Which way are _you_ going, Mr. Pig?"
noemo	"To market--I have two pig papers.
sadness	I might take you to the bridge; if you have no objection," said Pigling much confused and sitting on the edge of his coppy stool.
joy	Pig- wig's gratitude was such and she asked so many questions that it became embarrassing to Pigling Bland.
noemo	He was obliged to shut his eyes and pretend to sleep.
noemo	She became quiet, and there was a smell of peppermint.
noemo	"Only the corners," replied Pig- wig, studying the sentiments with much interest by the firelight.
fear	"I wish you wouldn't; he might smell them through the ceiling," said the alarmed Pigling.
noemo	Pig-wig put back the sticky peppermints into her pocket; "Sing something," she demanded.
noemo	"I am sorry.
noemo	. .
sadness	I have tooth- ache," said Pigling much dismayed.
noemo	"Then I will sing," replied Pig- wig, "You will not mind if I say iddy tidditty?
noemo	I have forgotten some of the words."
noemo	Pigling Bland made no objection; he sat with his eyes half shut, and watched her.
joy	She wagged her head and rocked about, clapping time and singing in a sweet little grunty voice--
noemo	"A funny old mother pig lived in a stye, and three little piggies had she; "(Ti idditty idditty) umph, umph, umph! and the little pigs said wee, wee!"
noemo	She sang successfully through three or four verses, only at every verse her head nodded a little lower, and her little twinkly eyes closed up--
noemo	"Those three little piggies grew peaky and lean, and lean they might very well be; "For somehow they couldn't say umph, umph, umph! and they wouldn't say wee, wee, wee!
noemo	"For somehow they couldn't say--
noemo	Pig-wig's head bobbed lower and lower, until she rolled over, a little round ball, fast asleep on the hearth-rug.
noemo	Pigling Bland, on tiptoe, covered her up with an antimacassar.
fear	He was afraid to go to sleep himself; for the rest of the night he sat listening to the chirping of the crickets and to the snores of Mr. Piperson overhead.
noemo	Early in the morning, between dark and daylight, Pigling tied up his little bundle and woke up Pig- wig.
fear	"But it's dark!
fear	How can we find our way?"
noemo	"The cock has crowed; we must start before the hens come out; they might shout to Mr. Piperson."
noemo	"Come away Pig-wig; we can see when we get used to it.
noemo	Come!
fear	I can hear them clucking!"
noemo	Pigling had never said shuh! to a hen in his life, being peaceable; also he remembered the hamper.
noemo	He opened the house door quietly and shut it after them.
noemo	There was no garden; the neighborhood of Mr. Piperson's was all scratched up by fowls.
noemo	They slipped away hand in hand across an untidy field to the road.
noemo	"Tom, Tom the piper's son, stole a pig and away he ran!
noemo	"But all the tune that he could play, was `Over the hills and far away!'"
noemo	"Come Pig-wig, we must get to the bridge before folks are stirring."
noemo	"Why do you want to go to market, Pigling?" inquired Pig-wig.
noemo	The sun rose while they were crossing the moor, a dazzle of light over the tops of the hills.
noemo	The sunshine crept down the slopes into the peaceful green valleys, where little white cottages nestled in gardens and orchards.
noemo	"That's Westmorland," said Pig- wig.
joy	She dropped Pigling's hand and commenced to dance, singing-- presently.
noemo	"I don't want; I want to grow potatoes."
noemo	"Have a peppermint?" said Pig-wig.
anger	Pigling Bland refused quite crossly.
noemo	"Does your poor toothy hurt?" inquired Pig- wig.
anger	Pigling Bland grunted.
noemo	Pig-wig ate the peppermint herself, and followed the opposite side of the road.
anger	"Pig-wig! keep under the wall, there's a man ploughing."
noemo	Pig-wig crossed over, they hurried down hill towards the county boundary.
fear	Suddenly Pigling stopped; he heard wheels.
noemo	Slowly jogging up the road below them came a tradesman's cart.
noemo	The reins flapped on the horse's back, the grocer was reading a newspaper.
fear	"Take that peppermint out of your mouth, Pig-wig, we may have to run.
fear	Don't say one word.
noemo	Leave it to me.
fear	And in sight of the bridge!" said poor Pigling, nearly crying.
fear	He began to walk frightfully lame, holding Pig-wig's arm.
noemo	The grocer, intent upon his newspaper, might have passed them, if his horse had not shied and snorted.
noemo	He pulled the cart crossways, and held down his whip.
noemo	"Hallo?
noemo	Where are you going to?"--Pigling Bland stared at him vacantly.
noemo	"Are you deaf?
noemo	Are you going to market?"
noemo	Pigling nodded slowly.
noemo	"I thought as much.
noemo	It was yesterday.
noemo	Show me your license?"
noemo	Pigling stared at the off hind shoe of the grocer's horse which had picked up a stone.
disgust	The grocer flicked his whip-- "Papers?
disgust	Pig license?"
noemo	Pigling fumbled in all his pockets, and handed up the papers.
disgust	The grocer read them, but still seemed dissatisfied.
surprise	"This here pig is a young lady; is her name Alexander?"
noemo	Pig-wig opened her mouth and shut it again; Pigling coughed asthmatically.
anger	The grocer ran his finger down the advertisement column of his newspaper--"Lost, stolen or strayed, 10S. reward;" he looked suspiciously at Pig-wig.
noemo	Then he stood up in the trap, and whistled for the ploughman.
noemo	"You wait here while I drive on and speak to him," said the grocer, gathering up the reins.
noemo	He knew that pigs are slippery; but surely, such a VERY lame pig could never run!
fear	"Not yet, Pig-wig, he will look back."
noemo	The grocer did so; he saw the two pigs stock-still in the middle of the road.
noemo	Then he looked over at his horse's heels; it was lame also; the stone took some time to knock out, after he got to the ploughman.
fear	"Now, Pig-wig, NOW!" said Pigling Bland.
noemo	Never did any pigs run as these pigs ran!
noemo	They raced and squealed and pelted down the long white hill towards the bridge.
fear	Little fat Pig- wig's petticoats fluttered, and her feet went pitter, patter, pitter, as she bounded and jumped.
noemo	They ran, and they ran, and they ran down the hill, and across a short cut on level green turf at the bottom, between pebble beds and rushes.
joy	They came to the river, they came to the bridge--they crossed it hand in hand--then over the hills and far away she danced with Pigling Bland!
noemo	This is a Pussy called Miss Moppet; she thinks she has heard a mouse!
noemo	He is not afraid of a kitten.
surprise	This is Miss Moppet jumping just too late; she misses the Mouse and hits her own head.
surprise	She thinks it is a very hard cupboard!
noemo	The Mouse watches Miss Moppet from the top of the cupboard.
noemo	Miss Moppet ties up her head in a duster and sits before the fire.
noemo	The Mouse thinks she is looking very ill.
noemo	He comes sliding down the bellpull.
noemo	Miss Moppet looks worse and worse.
noemo	The Mouse comes a little nearer.
noemo	Miss Moppet holds her poor head in her paws and looks at him through a hole in the duster.
noemo	The Mouse comes VERY close.
surprise	And then all of a sudden--Miss Moppet jumps upon the Mouse!
disgust	And because the Mouse has teased Miss Moppet--Miss Moppet thinks she will tease the Mouse, which is not at all nice of Miss Moppet.
noemo	She ties him up in the duster and tosses it about like a ball.
surprise	But she forgot about that hole in the duster; and when she untied it-- there was no Mouse!
joy	He has wriggled out and run away; and he is dancing a jig on top of the cupboard!
noemo	"I'll be at charges for a looking-glass; And entertain a score or two of tailors." [Richard III]
noemo	My Dear Freda:
noemo	Because you are fond of fairytales, and have been ill, I have made you a story all for yourself--a new one that nobody has read before.
noemo	And the queerest thing about it is--that I heard it in Gloucestershire, and that it is true--at least about the tailor, the waistcoat, and the "No more twist!" _Christmas_
noemo	In the time of swords and peri wigs and full-skirted coats with flowered lappets--when gentlemen wore ruffles, and gold-laced waistcoats of paduasoy and taffeta--there lived a tailor in Gloucester.
noemo	He sat in the window of a little shop in Westgate Street, cross-legged on a table from morning till dark.
noemo	All day long while the light lasted he sewed and snippetted, piecing out his satin, and pompadour, and lutestring; stuffs had strange names, and were very expensive in the days of the Tailor of Gloucester.
noemo	But although he sewed fine silk for his neighbours, he himself was very, very poor.
noemo	He cut his coats without waste; according to his embroidered cloth, they were very small ends and snippets that lay about upon the table--"Too narrow breadths for nought--except waistcoats for mice," said the tailor.
noemo	One bitter cold day near Christmastime the tailor began to make a coat (a coat of cherry- coloured corded silk embroidered with pansies and roses) and a cream- coloured satin waistcoat for the Mayor of Gloucester.
noemo	The tailor worked and worked, and he talked to himself: "No breadth at all, and cut on the cross; it is no breadth at all; tippets for mice and ribbons for mobs! for mice!" said the Tailor of Gloucester.
noemo	When the snow-flakes came down against the small leaded window- panes and shut out the light, the tailor had done his day's work; all the silk and satin lay cut out upon the table.
noemo	There were twelve pieces for the coat and four pieces for the waistcoat; and there were pocket-flaps and cuffs and buttons, all in order.
noemo	For the lining of the coat there was fine yellow taffeta, and for the button- holes of the waistcoat there was cherry-coloured twist.
noemo	And everything was ready to sew together in the morning, all measured and sufficient--except that there was wanting just one single skein of cherry-coloured twisted silk.
noemo	The tailor came out of his shop at dark.
noemo	No one lived there at nights but little brown mice, and THEY ran in and out without any keys!
noemo	For behind the wooden wainscots of all the old houses in Gloucester, there are little mouse staircases and secret trap-doors; and the mice run from house to house through those long, narrow passages.
noemo	But the tailor came out of his shop and shuffled home through the snow.
noemo	And although it was not a big house, the tailor was so poor he only rented the kitchen.
noemo	He lived alone with his cat; it was called Simpkin.
noemo	"Miaw?" said the cat when the tailor opened the door, "miaw?"
sadness	The tailor replied: "Simpkin, we shall make our fortune, but I am worn to a ravelling.
noemo	Take this groat (which is our last fourpence), and, Simpkin, take a china pipkin, but a penn'orth of bread, a penn'orth of milk, and a penn'orth of sausages.
noemo	And oh, Simpkin, with the last penny of our fourpence but me one penn'orth of cherry-coloured silk.
sadness	But do not lose the last penny of the fourpence, Simpkin, or I am undone and worn to a thread-paper, for I have NO MORE TWIST."
noemo	Then Simpkin again said "Miaw!" and took the groat and the pipkin, and went out into the dark.
sadness	The tailor was very tired and beginning to be ill.
noemo	He sat down by the hearth and talked to himself about that wonderful coat.
noemo	"I shall make my fortune--to be cut bias--the Mayor of Gloucester is to be married on Christmas Day in the morning, and he hath ordered a coat and an embroidered waistcoat--"
surprise	Then the tailor started; for suddenly, interrupting him, from the dresser at the other side of the kitchen came a number of little noises--
noemo	Tip tap, tip tap, tip tap tip!
surprise	"Now what can that be?" said the Tailor of Gloucester, jumping up from his chair.
noemo	The tailor crossed the kitchen, and stood quite still beside the dresser, listening, and peering through his spectacles.
surprise	"This is very peculiar," said the Tailor of Gloucester, and he lifted up the tea-cup which was upside down.
noemo	Out stepped a little live lady mouse, and made a courtesy to the tailor!
noemo	Then she hopped away down off the dresser, and under the wainscot.
noemo	The tailor sat down again by the fire, warming his poor cold hands.
noemo	But all at once, from the dresser, there came other little noises--
noemo	Tip tap, tip tap, tip tap tip!
noemo	Out stepped a little gentleman mouse, and made a bow to the tailor!
noemo	And out from under tea-cups and from under bowls and basins, stepped other and more little mice, who hopped away down off the dresser and under the wainscot.
sadness	The tailor sat down, close over the fire, lamenting: "One-and-twenty buttonholes of cherry-coloured silk!
noemo	To be finished by noon of Saturday: and this is Tuesday evening.
noemo	Was it right to let loose those mice, undoubtedly the property of Simpkin?
noemo	The little mice came out again and listened to the tailor; they took notice of the pattern of that wonderful coat.
noemo	They whispered to one another about the taffeta lining and about little mouse tippets.
noemo	And then suddenly they all ran away together down the passage behind the wainscot, squeaking and calling to one another as they ran from house to house.
noemo	Not one mouse was left in the tailor's kitchen when Simpkin came back.
surprise	He set down the pipkin of milk upon the dresser, and looked suspiciously at the tea-cups.
surprise	He wanted his supper of little fat mouse!
anger	"Simpkin," said the tailor, "where is my TWIST?"
anger	But Simpkin hid a little parcel privately in the tea-pot, and spit and growled at the tailor; and if Simpkin had been able to talk, he would have asked: "Where is my MOUSE?"
sadness	"Alack, I am undone!" said the Tailor of Gloucester, and went sadly to bed.
noemo	All that night long Simpkin hunted and searched through the kitchen, peeping into cupboards and under the wainscot, and into the tea-pot where he had hidden that twist; but still he found never a mouse!
sadness	The poor old tailor was very ill with a fever, tossing and turning in his four-post bed; and still in his dreams he mumbled: "No more twist! no more twist!"
noemo	What should become of the cherry- coloured coat?
noemo	Who should come to sew it, when the window was barred, and the door was fast locked?
noemo	Out-of-doors the market folks went trudging through the snow to buy their geese and turkeys, and to bake their Christmas pies; but there would be no dinner for Simpkin and the poor old tailor of Gloucester.
sadness	The tailor lay ill for three days and nights; and then it was Christmas Eve, and very late at night.
noemo	But it is in the old story that all the beasts can talk in the night between Christmas Eve and Christmas Day in the morning (though there are very few folk that can hear them, or know what it is that they say).
noemo	When the Cathedral clock struck twelve there was an answer--like an echo of the chimes--and Simpkin heard it, and came out of the tailor's door, and wandered about in the snow.
noemo	From all the roofs and gables and old wooden houses in Gloucester came a thousand merry voices singing the old Christmas rhymes--all the old songs that ever I heard of, and some that I don't know, like Whittington's bells.
noemo	Under the wooden eaves the starlings and sparrows sang of Christmas pies; the jackdaws woke up in the Cathedral tower; and although it was the middle of the night the throstles and robins sang; and air was quite full of little twittering tunes.
sadness	But it was all rather provoking to poor hungry Simpkin.
noemo	From the tailor's ship in Westgate came a glow of light; and when Simpkin crept up to peep in at the window it was full of candles.
joy	There was a snippeting of scissors, and snappeting of thread; and little mouse voices sang loudly and gaily:
noemo	"Four-and-twenty tailors Went to catch a snail, The best man amongst them Durst not touch her tail; She put out her horns Like a little kyloe cow.
noemo	Run, tailors, run!
noemo	Or she'll have you all e'en now!"
noemo	Then without a pause the little mouse voices went on again:
noemo	"Sieve my lady's oatmeal, Grind my lady's flour, Put it in a chestnut, Let it stand an hour--"
noemo	"Mew!
noemo	Mew!" interrupted Simpkin, and he scratched at the door.
noemo	But the key was under the tailor's pillow; he could not get in.
joy	The little mice only laughed, and tried another tune--
noemo	"Three little mice sat down to spin, Pussy passed by and she peeped in.
noemo	What are you at, my fine little men?
noemo	Making coats for gentlemen.
noemo	Shall I come in and cut off yours threads?
noemo	Oh, no, Miss Pussy, You'd bite off our heads!"
anger	"Mew! scratch! scratch!" scuffled Simpkin on the window-sill; while the little mice inside sprang to their feet, and all began to shout all at once in little twittering voices: "No more twist!
noemo	No more twist!"
noemo	And they barred up the window-shutters and shut out Simpkin.
noemo	Simpkin came away from the shop and went home considering in his mind.
joy	He found the poor old tailor without fever, sleeping peacefully.
noemo	The sun was shining on the snow when the tailor got up and dressed, and came out into the street with Simpkin running before him.
sadness	"Alack," said the tailor, "I have my twist; but no more strength--nor time--than will serve to make me one single buttonhole; for this is Christmas Day in the Morning!
sadness	The Mayor of Gloucester shall be married by noon--and where is his cherry- coloured coat?"
noemo	He unlocked the door of the little shop in Westgate Street, and Simpkin ran in, like a cat that expects something.
surprise	But there was no one there!
surprise	Not even one little brown mouse!
noemo	Everything was finished except just one single cherry-coloured buttonhole, and where that buttonhole was wanting there was pinned a scrap of paper with these words--in little teeny weeny writing--
noemo	NO MORE TWIST.
joy	And from then began the luck of the Tailor of Gloucester; he grew quite stout, and he grew quite rich.
noemo	He made the most wonderful waistcoats for all the rich merchants of Gloucester, and for all the fine gentlemen of the country round.
noemo	Never were seen such ruffles, or such embroidered cuffs and lappets!
noemo	But his buttonholes were the greatest triumph of it all.
noemo	The stitches of those buttonholes were so neat--SO neat--I wonder how they could be stitched by an old man in spectacles, with crooked old fingers, and a tailor's thimble.
noemo	The stitches of those buttonholes were so small--SO small--they looked as if they had been made by little mice!
noemo	It is said that the effect of eating too much lettuce is "soporific."
noemo	I have never felt sleepy after eating lettuces; but then I am not a rabbit.
noemo	They certainly had a very soporific effect upon the Flopsy Bunnies!
noemo	When Benjamin Bunny grew up, he married his Cousin Flopsy.
joy	They had a large family, and they were very improvident and cheerful.
noemo	I do not remember the separate names of their children; they were generally called the "Flopsy Bunnies."
noemo	As there was not always quite enough to eat,--Benjamin used to borrow cabbages from Flopsy's brother, Peter Rabbit, who kept a nursery garden.
noemo	Sometimes Peter Rabbit had no cabbages to spare.
noemo	When this happened, the Flopsy Bunnies went across the field to a rubbish heap, in the ditch outside Mr. McGregor's garden.
noemo	Mr. McGregor's rubbish heap was a mixture.
noemo	There were jam pots and paper bags, and mountains of chopped grass from the mowing machine (which always tasted oily), and some rotten vegetable marrows and an old boot or two.
joy	One day--oh joy!--there were a quantity of overgrown lettuces, which had "shot" into flower.
joy	The Flopsy Bunnies simply stuffed themselves with lettuces.
joy	By degrees, one after another, they were overcome with slumber, and lay down in the mown grass.
noemo	Benjamin was not so much overcome as his children.
noemo	Before going to sleep he was sufficiently wide awake to put a paper bag over his head to keep off the flies.
joy	The little Flopsy Bunnies slept delightfully in the warm sun.
noemo	From the lawn beyond the garden came the distant clacketty sound of the mowing machine.
noemo	The blue- bottles buzzed about the wall, and a little old mouse picked over the rubbish among the jam pots.
noemo	(I can tell you her name, she was called Thomasina Tittle- mouse, a woodmouse with a long tail.)
noemo	She rustled across the paper bag, and awakened Benjamin Bunny.
noemo	The mouse apologized profusely, and said that she knew Peter Rabbit.
noemo	While she and Benjamin were talking, close under the wall, they heard a heavy tread above their heads; and suddenly Mr. McGregor emptied out a sackful of lawn mowings right upon the top of the sleeping Flopsy Bunnies!
fear	Benjamin shrank down under his paper bag.
fear	The mouse hid in a jam pot.
joy	The little rabbits smiled sweetly in their sleep under the shower of grass; they did not awake because the lettuces had been so soporific.
joy	They dreamt that their mother Flopsy was tucking them up in a hay bed.
noemo	Mr. McGregor looked down after emptying his sack.
noemo	He saw some funny little brown tips of ears sticking up through the lawn mowings.
noemo	He stared at them for some time.
noemo	Presently a fly settled on one of them and it moved.
noemo	Mr. McGregor climbed down on to the rubbish heap--
anger	"One, two, three, four! five! six leetle rabbits!" said he as he dropped them into his sack.
joy	The Flopsy Bunnies dreamt that their mother was turning them over in bed.
noemo	They stirred a little in their sleep, but still they did not wake up.
noemo	Mr. McGregor tied up the sack and left it on the wall.
noemo	He went to put away the mowing machine.
noemo	While he was gone, Mrs. Flopsy Bunny (who had remained at home) came across the field.
noemo	Then the mouse came out of her jam pot, and Benjamin took the paper bag off his head, and they told the doleful tale.
noemo	But Mrs. Tittlemouse was a resourceful person.
noemo	She nibbled a hole in the bottom corner of the sack.
noemo	The little rabbits were pulled out and pinched to wake them.
noemo	Their parents stuffed the empty sack with three rotten vegetable marrows, an old blackingbrush and two decayed turnips.
fear	Then they all hid under a bush and watched for Mr. McGregor.
noemo	Mr. McGregor came back and picked up the sack, and carried it off.
noemo	He carried it hanging down, as if it were rather heavy.
noemo	The Flopsy Bunnies followed at a safe distance.
noemo	They watched him go into his house.
noemo	And then they crept up to the window to listen.
noemo	Mr. McGregor threw down the sack on the stone floor in a way that would have been extremely painful to the Flopsy Bunnies, if they had happened to have been inside it.
joy	They could hear him drag his chair on the flags, and chuckle--
joy	"One, two, three, four, five, six leetle rabbits!" said Mr. McGregor.
surprise	"Eh?
surprise	What's that?
surprise	What have they been spoiling now?" enquired Mrs. McGregor.
surprise	"One, two, three, four, five, six leetle fat rabbits!" repeated Mr. McGregor, counting on his fingers --"one, two, three--"
disgust	"Don't you be silly: what do you mean, you silly old man?"
surprise	"In the sack! one, two, three, four, five, six!" replied Mr. McGregor.
noemo	(The youngest Flopsy Bunny got upon the windowsill.)
noemo	Mrs. McGregor took hold of the sack and felt it.
noemo	She said she could feel six, but they must be OLD rabbits, because they were so hard and all different shapes.
noemo	"Not fit to eat; but the skins will do fine to line my old cloak."
disgust	"Line your old cloak?" shouted Mr. McGregor--"I shall sell them and buy myself baccy!"
noemo	"Rabbit tobacco!
joy	I shall skin them and cut off their heads."
noemo	Mrs. McGregor untied the sack and put her hand inside.
anger	When she felt the vegetables she became very very angry.
anger	She said that Mr. McGregor had "done it a purpose."
anger	And Mr. McGregor was very angry too.
noemo	One of the rotten marrows came flying through the kitchen window, and hit the youngest Flopsy Bunny.
noemo	Then Benjamin and Flopsy thought that it was time to go home.
noemo	So Mr. McGregor did not get his tobacco, and Mrs. McGregor did not get her rabbit skins.
noemo	But next Christmas Thomasina Tittlemouse got a present of enough rabbit wool to make herself a cloak and a hood, and a handsome muff and a pair of warm mittens.
noemo	What a funny sight it is to see a brood of ducklings with a hen!
anger	Listen to the story of Jemima Puddle-duck, who was annoyed because the farmer's wife would not let her hatch her own eggs.
anger	Her sister-in-law, Mrs. Rebeccah Puddle-duck, was perfectly willing to leave the hatching to someone else-- "I have not the patience to sit on a nest for twenty-eight days; and no more have you, Jemima.
anger	You would let them go cold; you know you would!"
anger	"I wish to hatch my own eggs; I will hatch them all by myself," quacked Jemima Puddle-duck.
noemo	She tried to hide her eggs; but they were always found and carried off.
noemo	She determined to make a nest right away from the farm.
noemo	She set off on a fine spring afternoon along the cart road that leads over the hill.
noemo	She was wearing a shawl and a poke bonnet.
noemo	When she reached the top of the hill, she saw a wood in the distance.
noemo	She thought that it looked a safe quiet spot.
noemo	Jemima Puddle-duck was not much in the habit of flying.
noemo	She ran downhill a few yards flapping her shawl, and then she jumped off into the air.
noemo	She flew beautifully when she had got a good start.
noemo	She skimmed along over the treetops until she saw an open place in the middle of the wood, where the trees and brushwood had been cleared.
noemo	Jemima alighted rather heavily and began to waddle about in search of a convenient dry nesting place.
joy	She rather fancied a tree stump amongst some tall foxgloves.
surprise	But--seated upon the stump, she was startled to find an elegantly dressed gentleman reading a newspaper.
noemo	He had black prick ears and sandy colored whiskers.
fear	"Quack?" said Jemima Puddle- duck, with her head and her bonnet on the one side--"Quack?"
noemo	The gentleman raised his eyes above his newspaper and looked curiously at Jemima--
noemo	"Madam, have you lost your way?" said he.
noemo	He had a long bushy tail which he was sitting upon, as the stump was somewhat damp.
noemo	Jemima thought him mighty civil and handsome.
noemo	She explained that she had not lost her way, but that she was trying to find a convenient dry nesting place.
noemo	"Ah! is that so?
joy	Indeed!" said the gentleman with sandy whiskers, looking curiously at Jemima.
noemo	He folded up the newspaper and put it in his coattail pocket.
anger	Jemima complained of the superfluous hen.
joy	"Indeed!
joy	How interesting!
noemo	I wish I could meet with that fowl.
noemo	I would teach it to mind its own business!
noemo	"But as to a nest--there is no difficulty: I have a sackful of feathers in my woodshed.
noemo	No, my dear madam, you will be in nobody's way.
noemo	You may sit there as long as you like," said the bushy long-tailed gentleman.
noemo	He led the way to a very retired, dismal-looking house amongst the foxgloves.
noemo	It was built of faggots and turf, and there were two broken pails, one on top of another, by way of a chimney.
noemo	"This is my summer residence; you would not find my earth--my winter house--so convenient," said the hospitable gentleman.
noemo	There was a tumbledown shed at the back of the house, made of old soap boxes.
noemo	The gentleman opened the door and showed Jemima in.
noemo	The shed was almost quite full of feathers--it was almost suffocating; but it was comfortable and very soft.
surprise	Jemima Puddle-duck was rather surprised to find such a vast quantity of feathers.
surprise	But it was very comfortable; and she made a nest without any trouble at all.
noemo	When she came out, the sandy- whiskered gentleman was sitting on a log reading the newspaper--at least he had it spread out, but he was looking over the top of it.
sadness	He was so polite that he seemed almost sorry to let Jemima go home for the night.
noemo	He promised to take great care of her nest until she came back again the next day.
joy	He said he loved eggs and ducklings; he should be proud to see a fine nestful in his woodshed.
noemo	Jemima Puddle-duck came every afternoon; she laid nine eggs in the nest.
noemo	They were greeny white and very large.
joy	The foxy gentleman admired them immensely.
joy	He used to turn them over and count them when Jemima was not there.
noemo	At last Jemima told him that she intended to begin to sit next day--"and I will bring a bag of corn with me, so that I need never leave my nest until the eggs are hatched.
noemo	They might catch cold," said the conscientious Jemima.
noemo	"Madam, I beg you not to trouble yourself with a bag; I will provide oats.
noemo	But before you commence your tedious sitting, I intend to give you a treat.
joy	Let us have a dinner party all to ourselves!
noemo	"May I ask you to bring up some herbs from the farm garden to make a savory omelet?
noemo	Sage and thyme, and mint and two onions, and some parsley.
noemo	I will provide lard for the stuff--lard for the omelet," said the hospitable gentleman with sandy whiskers.
noemo	Jemima Puddle-duck was a simpleton: not even the mention of sage and onions made her suspicious.
noemo	She went round the farm garden, nibbling off snippets of all the different sorts of herbs that are used for stuffing roast duck.
noemo	And she waddled into the kitchen and got two onions out of a basket.
noemo	The collie dog Kep met her coming out, "What are you doing with those onions?
noemo	Where do you go every afternoon by yourself, Jemima Puddle-duck?"
joy	The collie listened, with his wise head on one side; he grinned when she described the polite gentleman with sandy whiskers.
noemo	He asked several questions about the wood and about the exact position of the house and shed.
noemo	Then he went out, and trotted down the village.
noemo	He went to look for two foxhound puppies who were out at walk with the butcher.
noemo	Jemima Puddle-duck went up the cart road for the last time, on a sunny afternoon.
noemo	She was rather burdened with bunches of herbs and two onions in a bag.
noemo	She flew over the wood, and alighted opposite the house of the bushy long-tailed gentleman.
fear	He was sitting on a log; he sniffed the air and kept glancing uneasily round the wood.
noemo	"Come into the house as soon as you have looked at your eggs.
noemo	Give me the herbs for the omelet.
anger	Be sharp!"
fear	He was rather abrupt.
noemo	Jemima Puddle-duck had never heard him speak like that.
surprise	She felt surprised and uncomfortable.
noemo	While she was inside she heard pattering feet round the back of the shed.
noemo	Someone with a black nose sniffed at the bottom of the door, and them locked it.
fear	Jemima became much alarmed.
noemo	A moment afterward there were most awful noises--barking, baying, growls and howls, squealing and groans.
noemo	And nothing more was ever seen of that foxy-whiskered gentleman.
noemo	Presently Kep opened the door of the shed and let out Jemima Puddle- duck.
noemo	Unfortunately the puppies rushed in and gobbled up all the eggs before he could stop them.
noemo	He had a bite on his ear, and both the puppies were limping.
sadness	Jemima Puddle-duck was escorted home in tears on account of those eggs.
noemo	She laid some more in June, and she was permitted to keep them herself: but only four of them hatched.
noemo	Jemima Puddle-duck said that it was because of her nerves; but she had always been a bad sitter.
noemo	Once upon a time there was a little girl called Lucie, who lived at a farm called Little-town.
noemo	She was a good little girl--only she was always losing her pocket-handkerchiefs!
sadness	One day little Lucie came into the farm-yard crying--oh, she did cry so!
sadness	"I've lost my pocket-handkin!
sadness	Three handkins and a pinny!
sadness	Have YOU seen them, Tabby Kitten?"
noemo	The Kitten went on washing her white paws; so Lucie asked a speckled hen--
sadness	"Sally Henny-penny, have YOU found three pocket-handkins?"
noemo	But the speckled hen ran into a barn, clucking--
noemo	"I go barefoot, barefoot, barefoot!"
noemo	And then Lucie asked Cock Robin sitting on a twig.
noemo	Cock Robin looked sideways at Lucie with his bright black eye, and he flew over a stile and away.
noemo	Lucie climbed upon the stile and looked up at the hill behind Little- town--a hill that goes up--up--into the clouds as though it had no top!
surprise	And a great way up the hillside she thought she saw some white things spread upon the grass.
noemo	Lucie scrambled up the hill as fast as her short legs would carry her; she ran along a steep path-way--up and up--until Little-town was right away down below--she could have dropped a pebble down the chimney!
noemo	Presently she came to a spring, bubbling out from the hillside.
noemo	Some one had stood a tin can upon a stone to catch the water--but the water was already running over, for the can was no bigger than an egg- cup!
noemo	And where the sand upon the path was wet--there were footmarks of a VERY small person.
noemo	Lucie ran on, and on.
noemo	The path ended under a big rock.
surprise	The grass was short and green, and there were clothes-props cut from bracken stems, with lines of plaited rushes, and a heap of tiny clothes pins--but no pocket-handkerchiefs!
noemo	But there was something else--a door! straight into the hill; and inside it some one was singing--
noemo	"Lily-white and clean, oh!
noemo	With little frills between, oh!
noemo	Smooth and hot-red rusty spot Never here be seen, oh!"
noemo	Lucie knocked-once-twice, and interrupted the song.
fear	A little frightened voice called out "Who's that?"
noemo	Lucie opened the door: and what do you think there was inside the hill?--a nice clean kitchen with a flagged floor and wooden beams-- just like any other farm kitchen.
noemo	Only the ceiling was so low that Lucie's head nearly touched it; and the pots and pans were small, and so was everything there.
fear	There was a nice hot singey smell; and at the table, with an iron in her hand, stood a very stout short person staring anxiously at Lucie.
noemo	Her print gown was tucked up, and she was wearing a large apron over her striped petticoat.
surprise	Her little black nose went sniffle, sniffle, snuffle, and her eyes went twinkle, twinkle; and underneath her cap-where Lucie had yellow curls-that little person had PRICKLES!
noemo	"Who are you?" said Lucie.
noemo	"Have you seen my pocket-handkins?"
joy	The little person made a bob- curtsey--"Oh yes, if you please'm; my name is Mrs. Tiggy-winkle; oh yes if you please'm, I'm an excellent clear- starcher!"
noemo	And she took something out of the clothesbasket, and spread it on the ironing-blanket.
noemo	"What's that thing?" said Lucie- "that's not my pocket-handkin?"
noemo	"Oh no, if you please'm; that's a little scarlet waist-coat belonging to Cock Robin!"
noemo	And she ironed it and folded it, and put it on one side.
noemo	Then she took something else off a clothes-horse--"That isn't my pinny?" said Lucie.
noemo	"Oh no, if you please'm; that's a damask table-cloth belonging to Jenny Wren; look how it's stained with currant wine!
disgust	It's very bad to wash!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
noemo	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle's nose went sniffle sniffle snuffle, and her eyes went twinkle twinkle; and she fetched another hot iron from the fire.
noemo	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle ironed it, and goffered it, and shook out the frills.
joy	"Oh that IS lovely!" said Lucie.
noemo	"And what are those long yellow things with fingers like gloves?"
noemo	"Oh that's a pair of stockings belonging to Sally Henny-penny--look how she's worn the heels out with scratching in the yard!
noemo	She'll very soon go barefoot!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
noemo	"Why, there's another hankersniff-- but it isn't mine; it's red?"
disgust	"Oh no, if you please'm; that one belongs to old Mrs. Rabbit; and it DID so smell of onions!
disgust	I've had to wash it separately, I can't get out that smell."
surprise	"There's another one of mine," said Lucie.
noemo	"What are those funny little white things?"
noemo	"That's a pair of mittens belonging to Tabby Kitten; I only have to iron them; she washes them herself."
surprise	"There's my last pocket-handkin!" said Lucie.
noemo	"And what are you dipping into the basin of starch?"
noemo	"They're little dicky shirt-fronts belonging to Tom Titmouse--most terrible particular!" said Mrs. Tiggy- winkle.
noemo	"Now I've finished my ironing; I'm going to air some clothes."
noemo	"What are these dear soft fluffy things?" said Lucie.
noemo	"Oh those are woolly coats belonging to the little lambs at Skelghyl."
noemo	"Will their jackets take off?" asked Lucie.
noemo	"Oh yes, if you please'm; look at the sheep-mark on the shoulder.
noemo	And here's one marked for Gatesgarth, and three that come from Little-town.
noemo	They're ALWAYS marked at washing!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
noemo	And she hung up all sorts and sizes of clothes--small brown coats of mice; and one velvety black moleskin waist-coat; and a red tail-coat with no tail belonging to Squirrel Nutkin; and a very much shrunk blue jacket belonging to Peter Rabbit; and a petticoat, not marked, that had gone lost in the washing--and at last the basket was empty!
noemo	Then Mrs. Tiggy-winkle made tea--a cup for herself and a cup for Lucie.
noemo	They sat before the fire on a bench and looked sideways at one another.
disgust	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle's hand, holding the tea-cup, was very very brown, and very very wrinkly with the soap-suds; and all through her gown and her cap, there were HAIRPINS sticking wrong end out; so that Lucie didn't like to sit too near her.
noemo	When they had finished tea, they tied up the clothes in bundles; and Lucie's pocket-handkerchiefs were folded up inside her clean pinny, and fastened with a silver safety-pin.
noemo	And then they made up the fire with turf, and came out and locked the door, and hid the key under the door-sill.
noemo	Then away down the hill trotted Lucie and Mrs. Tiggy-winkle with the bundles of clothes!
noemo	All the way down the path little animals came out of the fern to meet them; the very first that they met were Peter Rabbit and Benjamin Bunny!
joy	And she gave them their nice clean clothes; and all the little animals and birds were so very much obliged to dear Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
noemo	So that at the bottom of the hill when they came to the stile, there was nothing left to carry except Lucie's one little bundle.
surprise	Lucie scrambled up the stile with the bundle in her hand; and then she turned to say "Good-night," and to thank the washer-woman.--But what a VERY odd thing!
surprise	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle had not waited either for thanks or for the washing bill!
noemo	She was running running running up the hill--and where was her white frilled cap? and her shawl? and her gown-and her petticoat?
noemo	And HOW small she had grown-- and HOW brown--and covered with PRICKLES!
noemo	Why!
surprise	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle was nothing but a HEDGEHOG! * * * * * *
noemo	(Now some people say that little Lucie had been asleep upon the stile--but then how could she have found three clean pocket-handkins and a pinny, pinned with a silver safety-pin?
noemo	And besides--I have seen that door into the back of the hill called Cat Bells--and besides _I_ am very well acquainted with dear Mrs. Tiggy-winkle!)
noemo	One morning a little rabbit sat on a bank.
noemo	He pricked his ears and listened to the trit-trot, trit-trot of a pony.
noemo	A gig was coming along the road; it was driven by Mr. McGregor, and beside him sat Mrs. McGregor in her best bonnet.
surprise	He came round the back of the fir- tree, and nearly tumbled upon the top of his Cousin Peter.
sadness	He looked poorly, and was dressed in a red cotton pocket-handkerchief.
sadness	Peter replied, "The scarecrow in Mr. McGregor's garden," and described how he had been chased about the garden, and had dropped his shoes and coat.
fear	Peter did not seem to be enjoying himself; he kept hearing noises.
joy	Benjamin, on the contrary, was perfectly at home, and ate a lettuce leaf.
fear	Peter did not eat anything; he said he should like to go home.
joy	He led the way boldly towards the other end of the garden.
joy	The mice sat on their doorsteps cracking cherry-stones; they winked at Peter Rabbit and little Benjamin Bunny.
fear	Peter heard noises worse than ever; his eyes were as big as lolly-pops!
fear	I cannot draw you a picture of Peter and Benjamin underneath the basket, because it was quite dark, and because the smell of onions was fearful; it made Peter Rabbit and little Benjamin cry.
surprise	The cat was too much surprised to scratch back.
anger	Then he came back to the basket and took out his son Benjamin by the ears, and whipped him with the little switch.
surprise	When Mr. McGregor returned about half an hour later he observed several things which perplexed him.
surprise	Also he could not understand how the cat could have managed to shut herself up INSIDE the greenhouse, locking the door upon the OUTSIDE.
joy	When Peter got home his mother forgave him, because she was so glad to see that he had found his shoes and coat.
fear	Tom Thumb and Hunca Munca went cautiously across the hearthrug.
joy	Then they squeaked with joy!
surprise	The knife crumpled up and hurt him; he put his finger in his mouth.
surprise	"It is not boiled enough; it is hard.
disgust	"It's as hard as the hams at the cheesemonger's," said Hunca Munca.
anger	Then Tom Thumb lost his temper.
anger	Then there was no end to the rage and disappointment of Tom Thumb and Hunca Munca.
anger	Then those mice set to work to do all the mischief they could--especially Tom Thumb!
fear	The mice rushed back to their hole, and the dolls came into the nursery.
surprise	What a sight met the eyes of Jane and Lucinda!
sadness	Lucinda sat upon the upset kitchen stove and stared; and Jane leant against the kitchen dresser and smiled--but neither of them made any remark.
joy	The little girl that the doll's-house belonged to, said,--"I will get a doll dressed like a policeman!"
disgust	But the nurse said,--"I will set a mouse-trap!"
fear	The good Rabbit creeps away and hides in a hole.
sadness	It feels sad.
joy	He thinks it is a very funny bird!
disgust	The rabbits could not bear him; they could smell him half a mile off.
fear	One day he was living in a stick- house in the coppice [grove], causing terror to the family of old Mr. Benjamin Bouncer.
fear	Next day he moved into a pollard willow near the lake, frightening the wild ducks and the water rats.
anger	He was friendly with old Mr. Bouncer; they agreed in disliking the wicked otters and Mr. Tod; they often talked over that painful subject.
anger	He complained bitterly about the scarcity of pheasants' eggs, and accused Mr. Tod of poaching them.
anger	And the otters had cleared off all the frogs while he was asleep in winter--"I have not had a good square meal for a fort- night, I am living on pig-nuts.
anger	I shall have to turn vegetarian and eat my own tail!" said Tommy Brock.
joy	It was not much of a joke, but it tickled old Mr. Bouncer; because Tommy Brock was so fat and stumpy and grinning.
joy	So old Mr. Bouncer laughed; and pressed Tommy Brock to come inside, to taste a slice of seed cake and "a glass of my daughter Flopsy's cowslip wine."
joy	Then old Mr. Bouncer smoked another pipe, and gave Tommy Brock a cabbage leaf cigar which was so very strong that it made Tommy Brock grin more than ever; and the smoke filled the burrow.
joy	Old Mr. Bouncer coughed and laughed; and Tommy Brock puffed and grinned.
joy	And Mr. Bouncer laughed and coughed, and shut his eyes because of the cabbage smoke ..........
fear	Mr. Bouncer would not confess that he had admitted anybody into the rabbit hole.
anger	Benjamin Bunny set off at once after Tommy Brock.
fear	Benjamin stamped his foot, and bolted.
joy	Other rabbits were coming out to enjoy the evening air.
surprise	Peter Rabbit, Peter Rabbit!" shouted Benjamin Bunny.
