surprise	The blue coated rabbit sat up with pricked ears--"Whatever is the matter, Cousin Benjamin?
surprise	Is it a cat? or John Stoat Ferret?"
fear	"No, no, no!
fear	He's bagged my family--Tommy Brock--in a sack --have you seen him?"
surprise	"Tommy Brock? how many, Cousin Benjamin?"
fear	"Seven, Cousin Peter, and all of them twins!
fear	Did he come this way?
fear	Please tell me quick!"
fear	"Which way? which way has he gone, Cousin Peter?"
sadness	"My Uncle Bouncer has displayed a lamentable want of discretion for his years;" said Peter reflectively, "but there are two hopeful circumstances.
fear	"Which way?"
fear	Peter hid his dandelions, and accompanied the afflicted parent, who was all of atwitter.
surprise	"He must be very puffed; we are close behind him, by the scent.
disgust	What a nasty person!" said Peter.
fear	He had nodded, and pointed to the sack, and seemed doubled up with laughing.--"Come away, Peter; he will be cooking them; come quicker!" said Benjamin Bunny.
fear	Come on, Cousin Benjamin!"
fear	When they came near the wood at the top of Bull Banks, they went cautiously.
fear	The rabbits crept up carefully, listening and peeping.
joy	Benjamin sighed with relief.
fear	The rabbits shivered in their shoes.
fear	Benjamin, who was all of atwitter, pulled Peter off the windowsill.
fear	There were many unpleasant things lying about that had much better have been buried; rabbit bones and skulls, and chickens' legs and other horrors.
sadness	But alas, no little rabbit babies were to be seen!
surprise	And presently at the same moment Peter and Benjamin noticed that whenever they shook the window the little door opposite shook in answer.
surprise	The young family were alive; shut up in the oven!
joy	Benjamin was so excited that it was a mercy he did not awake Tommy Brock, whose snores continued solemnly in Mr. Tod's bed.
fear	Then those two rabbits lost their heads completely.
fear	They rushed into their short new tunnel, and hid themselves at the top end of it, under Mr. Tod's kitchen floor.
anger	Mr. Tod was coming up Bull Banks, and he was in the very worst of tempers.
anger	First he had been upset by breaking the plate.
anger	Then the midges had been very bad.
anger	And he had failed to catch a hen pheasant on her nest; and it had contained only five eggs, two of them addled.
anger	Mr. Tod had had an unsatisfactory night.
anger	As usual, when out of humor, he determined to move house.
anger	He made his way up the hill; his temper was not improved by noticing unmistakable marks of badger.
anger	Mr. Tod slapped his stick upon the earth and fumed; he guessed where Tommy Brock had gone to.
anger	He was further annoyed by the jay bird which followed him persistently.
anger	Once when it flew screaming over his head Mr. Tod snapped at it, and barked.
anger	The sight that met Mr. Tod's eyes in Mr. Tod's kitchen made Mr. Tod furious.
anger	His whiskers bristled and his coat collar stood on end with rage.
anger	When he was outside the house, he scratched up the earth with fury.
fear	But when he was inside --he did not like the look of Tommy Brock's teeth.
disgust	He was an incurably indolent person; he was not in the least afraid of Mr. Tod; he was simply too lazy and comfortable to move.
surprise	It creaked; he turned round with a jump.
fear	The snores were almost apoplectic; but the grin was not quite so big.
joy	"I will wake him up with an unpleasant surprise," said Mr. Tod.
joy	The moment he had gone, Tommy Brock got up in a hurry; he rolled Mr. Tod's dressing-gown into a bundle, put it into the bed beneath the pail of water instead of himself, and left the room also-- grinning immensely.
surprise	At last the rope gave way with such a sudden jerk that it nearly pulled his teeth out, and quite knocked him over backwards.
joy	Yes--there was no doubt about it--it had turned out even better than he had planned; the pail had hit poor old Tommy Brock, and killed him dead!
joy	"I will bury that nasty person in the hole which he has dug.
disgust	I must have a disinfecting.
joy	He was quite dry himself and grinning; and he threw the cup of scalding tea all over Mr. Tod.
anger	Then Mr. Tod rushed upon Tommy Brock, and Tommy Brock grappled with Mr. Tod amongst the broken crockery, and there was a terrific battle all over the kitchen.
fear	To the rabbits underneath it sounded as if the floor would give way at each crash of falling furniture.
fear	They crept out of their tunnel, and hung about amongst the rocks and bushes, listening anxiously.
fear	Inside the house the racket was fearful.
fear	The rabbit babies in the oven woke up trembling; perhaps it was fortunate they were shut up inside.
joy	When the kettle fell, Tommy Brock, who was still grinning, happened to be uppermost; and he rolled Mr. Tod over and over like a log, out at the door.
anger	Then the snarling and worrying went on outside; and they rolled over the bank, and down hill, bumping over the rocks.
anger	There will never be any love lost between Tommy Brock and Mr. Tod.
joy	"Now for it!
joy	Run in, Cousin Benjamin!
joy	Run in and get them! while I watch the door."
fear	But Benjamin was frightened--
fear	"Oh; oh! they are coming back!"
fear	"Yes they are!"
anger	At home in the rabbit hole, things had not been quite comfortable.
anger	After quarreling at supper, Flopsy and old Mr. Bouncer had passed a sleepless night, and quarrelled again at breakfast.
anger	Old Mr. Bouncer could no longer deny that he had invited company into the rabbit hole; but he refused to reply to the questions and reproaches of Flopsy.
anger	Old Mr. Bouncer, very sulky, was huddled up in a corner, barricaded with a chair.
fear	Old Mr. Bouncer, behind his chair, was wondering anxiously what she would do next.
fear	In Mr. Tod's kitchen, amidst the wreckage, Benjamin Bunny picked his way to the oven nervously, through a thick cloud of dust.
joy	"I've got them!
joy	Great was old Mr. Bouncer's relief and Flopsy's joy when Peter and Benjamin arrived in triumph with the young family.
sadness	The rabbit babies were rather tumbled and very hungry; they were fed and put to bed.
joy	He was rather upon his dignity; but he accepted.
joy	Old Mr. Bouncer was forgiven, and they all had dinner.
joy	The sun shone among the delicate leaves; everything breathed forth the loveliest fragrance, and all felt as we do when we are filled with joy at the thought of our happiness.
joy	"How beautiful existence is!" said each rose.
joy	We have good neighbours, both below and above.
joy	How beautiful existence is!"
disgust	"If you must ask questions, ask sensible ones," said their mother.
disgust	"Don't you see that they are feathers, such as I wear and you will wear too?
surprise	I am very curious to know what the ducks were so startled about; not about us, certainly, although I did say 'peep' to you pretty loudly.
disgust	The thick-headed roses ought to know why, but they know nothing at all; they only look at themselves and smell.
disgust	I am heartily tired of such neighbours."
joy	What a pleasure that must be!
joy	It is fine to have such cheerful neighbours."
surprise	The other roses looked after their sister, and asked each other, "Where can she be going to?"
joy	The whole day long the sun shines bright and warm, and in the night the sky shines more beautifully still; we can see that through all the little holes in it."
joy	"We make it lively about the house," said the sparrow-mother; "and people say that a swallows' nest brings luck; so they are glad of us.
disgust	But such neighbours as ours!
disgust	The roses are good for nothing but to be looked at and to be smelt, or at most to be stuck in a hat.
disgust	You see, that's their life; they exist only for the eye and the nose.
joy	But they were very pleased with it, and wondered whether all the little sparrows could become nightingales.
disgust	"Nothing at all," answered their mother; "that's only something external.
disgust	If they were only plucked a little they would look no better than the rest of us.
disgust	I would have plucked them already if they had not been so big."
joy	In the farmhouse lived a young married couple; they loved each other dearly, were industrious and active, and everything in their home looked very nice.
joy	"Now I see that it is Sunday," said the husband, kissing his little wife.
joy	They sat down, read their hymn-book, and held each other by the hand, while the sun shone down upon the fresh roses and upon them.
disgust	"This sight is really too tedious," said the sparrow-mother, who could see into the room from her nest; and she flew away.
surprise	In one of her flights, however it may have happened, she was caught, before she was aware of it, in a horse-hair net which some boys had attached to a tree.
fear	The horse-hair was drawn tightly round her leg- as tightly as if the latter were to be cut off; she was in great pain and terror.
joy	He was a merry old man, always wandering about.
fear	At these words an icy shudder ran through the sparrow-mother.
fear	But she, trembling in every limb, did not think of the adornment.
fear	"Now you will see the gold-jacket fly," said the old man, letting the sparrow go, which flew away in deadly fear, with the sun shining upon her.
surprise	How she glittered!
surprise	All the sparrows, and even a crow- and an old boy he was too- were startled at the sight; but still they flew after her to learn what kind of strange bird she was.
fear	Driven by fear and horror, she flew homeward; she was almost sinking fainting to the earth, while the flock of pursuing birds increased, some even attempting to peck at her.
surprise	"Look at her!
surprise	Look at her!" they all cried.
surprise	"Look at her!
surprise	Look at her" cried her little ones. as she approached the nest.
surprise	"That is certainly a young peacock, for it glitters in all colours; it makes one's eyes ache, as mother told us.
surprise	Peep! that's 'the beautiful'."
sadness	And then they pecked at the bird with their little beaks so that it was impossible for her to get into the nest; she was so exhausted that she couldn't even say "Peep!" much less "I am your own mother!"
sadness	"Poor creature!" said all the roses; "only be still, and we will hide you.
surprise	The sparrow spread out her wings once more, then drew them closely to her, and lay dead near the neighbouring family, the beautiful fresh roses.
anger	"But I am the eldest!" exclaimed the third.
anger	Then they all got excited; they hit out with their wings, pecked with their beaks, and flop! one after another was thrown out of the nest.
anger	There they lay with their anger, holding their heads on one side and blinking the eye that was turned upwards.
surprise	In the night the red flames burst through the window and seized the roof, the dry straw blazed up high, and the whole house, together with the young sparrow, was burned.
joy	"A pleasanter picture cannot be imagined.
surprise	"Where is the house?" they asked.
surprise	"Where is the nest?
surprise	All is burned and our strong brother too.

disgust	She eats too many, and the best ones too.
disgust	How she lifts her crest, the ugly, spiteful creature!
sadness	The sparrows ate lustily; they listened attentively, and even stood in the ranks with the others, but it did not suit them at all.
joy	They were full, and so they left the pigeons, exchanging opinions about them, slipped in under the garden palings, and when they found the door leading into the house open, one of them, who was more than full, and therefore felt brave, hopped on to the threshold.
surprise	"Peep!" said the sparrows, "it's nothing.
disgust	It only looks like something.
surprise	Peep! that is 'the beautiful.'
joy	The pigeons had often cooed, not to say growled- the spiteful creatures; the sparrows had been frozen in winter and had lived merrily in summer: they were all betrothed, or married, or whatever you like to call it.
joy	The windows of the house were broader at the bottom than at the top, and when the sparrows looked through them, every room appeared to them like a tulip with the brightest colours and shades.
joy	"How it shines! how it shines!" said the maiden sparrow.
joy	"I suppose that is 'the beautiful.'
surprise	A "peep" and three foot-scrapings- in this way she had often greeted throughout the year, and no one here had responded, for those who are once parted do not meet every day; and so this greeting had become a habit with her.
joy	Good-day! good-day!"
joy	This is 'the beautiful.'
joy	All stood with enraptured faces round Thorwaldsen's grave, and a few picked up the fallen rose-leaves and preserved them.
surprise	"Peep!" they said sweeping the ground with their tails, and blinking with one eye at the roses, they had not looked at them long before they were convinced that they were their old neighbours.
joy	The painter who had drawn the rose-bush near the ruined house, had afterwards obtained permission to dig it up, and had given it to the architect, for finer roses had never been seen.
joy	The roses nodded; they recognized their grey neighbours and were pleased to see them again.
joy	"How glorious it is to live and to bloom, to see old friends again, and happy faces every day.
joy	It is as if every day were a festival."
joy	Peep! how they have got on.
surprise	THERE lived once upon a time a wicked prince whose heart and mind were set upon conquering all the countries of the world, and on frightening the people; he devastated their countries with fire and sword, and his soldiers trod down the crops in the fields and destroyed the peasants' huts by fire, so that the flames licked the green leaves off the branches, and the fruit hung dried up on the singed black trees.
joy	The prince was of opinion that all this was right, and that it was only the natural course which things ought to take.
fear	His power increased day by day, his name was feared by all, and fortune favoured his deeds.
sadness	But they did not know what endless misery he had brought upon other countries, nor did they hear the sighs and lamentations which rose up from the debris of the destroyed cities.
joy	The prince often looked with delight upon his gold and his magnificent edifices, and thought, like the crowd: "What a mighty prince!
joy	No power on earth must equal mine, far less exceed it."
surprise	The conquered kings were chained up with golden fetters to his chariot when he drove through the streets of his city.
sadness	These kings had to kneel at his and his courtiers' feet when they sat at table, and live on the morsels which they left.
disgust	"Then I will conquer God too."
anger	"I will conquer God!" said the prince.
anger	"I have sworn it: my will must be done!"
anger	They buzzed round the prince and stung his face and hands; angrily he drew his sword and brandished it, but he only touched the air and did not hit the gnats.
anger	Mad with pain, he tore off the coverings and his clothes too, flinging them far away, and danced about before the eyes of his ferocious soldiers, who now mocked at him, the mad prince, who wished to make war with God, and was overcome by a single little gnat.
sadness	"Who is the dead man?" we asked.
sadness	"They say that he was once an energetic young man, that he studied the dead languages, and sang and even composed many songs; then something had happened to him, and in consequence of this he gave himself up to drink, body and mind.
sadness	When at last he had ruined his health, they brought him into the country, where someone paid for his board and residence.
anger	He was gentle as a child as long as the sullen mood did not come over him; but when it came he was fierce, became as strong as a giant, and ran about in the wood like a chased deer.
sadness	But when we succeeded in bringing him home, and prevailed upon him to open the book with the dried-up plants in it, he would sometimes sit for a whole day looking at this or that plant, while frequently the tears rolled over his cheeks.
sadness	God knows what was in his mind; but he requested us to put the book into his coffin, and now he lies there.
sadness	In a little while the lid will be placed upon the coffin, and he will have sweet rest in the grave!"
joy	The cloth which covered his face was lifted up; the dead man's face expressed peace- a sunbeam fell upon it.
sadness	What a strange feeling it is- surely we all know it- to look through old letters of our young days; a different life rises up out of the past, as it were, with all its hopes and sorrows.
joy	He fixed the leaf to the student's cap in the green wood, when they vowed eternal friendship.
sadness	Where does he dwell now?
sadness	The leaf is kept, but the friendship does no longer exist.
sadness	Here is a water-lily that he had plucked himself, and watered with salt tears- a lily of sweet water.
sadness	What might he have thought when he plucked and kept it?
sadness	The lilac bends its fresh fragrant flowers over the dead man's head; the swallow passes again- "twit, twit;" now the men come with hammer and nails, the lid is placed over the dead man, while his head rests on the dumb book- so long cherished, now closed for ever!
anger	"He annoys me with his loud crowing," said the Portuguese duck; "but, still, he's a handsome bird, there's no denying that, although he's not a drake.

disgust	"That's just like the cat, she's a villain," said the Portuguese duck.

joy	"I have never thought about my heart," replied the Portuguese duck, "but I know that I love all my fellow-creatures, except the cat, and nobody can expect me to love her, for she ate up two of my ducklings.
disgust	"Don't plague him so, interposed the Portuguese duck; "he requires rest and nursing.
surprise	"Oh, no! no! pray let me dry," implored the little bird.
joy	"Amusement, too, is very beneficial.
joy	The two Chinese were quite enchanted with the appearance of the singing-bird.
joy	"He's charming," they said to each other, and began a conversation with him in whispers, using the most aristocratic Chinese dialect: "We are of the same race as yourself," they said.
disgust	It cannot even be said of the ducks, and we warn you, little bird, not to trust that one yonder, with the short tail feathers, for she is cunning; that curiously marked one, with the crooked stripes on her wings, is a mischief-maker, and never lets any one have the last word, though she is always in the wrong.
disgust	That fat duck yonder speaks evil of every one, and that is against our principles.
anger	"I wonder what those two Chinese are whispering about," whispered one duck to another; "they are always doing it, and it annoys me.

anger	"You'll kill me with your crowing," she cried, "it's all your fault.

joy	That last flap of the wings was so easy and graceful, that I shall give you permission to fly with me to-morrow to the marshes.

anger	"But may we not punish those naughty boys?" asked the young storks.

anger	The young storks were very angry, and grew worse as they grew older; so at last their mother was obliged to promise that they should be revenged, but not until the day of their departure.
joy	"Yes, certainly," cried the mother stork.

joy	This person, moreover, maintained that he belonged to a very old family in the land of Egypt, and that he was highly esteemed there.

surprise	That was very mean.
anger	The Grasshopper only sprang half as high, but he sprang straight into the King's face, and the King declared that was horribly rude.
