anger	I jumped to the highest; but in this world a body is required if one wishes to be seen."
anger	And he too said, "Body is required! body is required!"
sadness	And then he sang his own melancholy song, and from that we have gathered this story, which they say is not true, though it's in print.
sadness	In this snug retreat sat a duck on her nest, watching for her young brood to hatch; she was beginning to get tired of her task, for the little ones were a long time coming out of their shells, and she seldom had any visitors.
joy	"How large the world is," said the young ducks, when they found how much more room they now had than while they were inside the egg-shell.
sadness	I wonder how long this is to last, I am quite tired of it;" and she seated herself again on the nest.
anger	"One egg is not hatched yet," said the duck, "it will not break.
joy	But just look at all the others, are they not the prettiest little ducklings you ever saw?
surprise	It was very large and ugly.
surprise	The duck stared at it and exclaimed, "It is very large and not at all like the others.
surprise	"Oh," said the mother, "that is not a turkey; how well he uses his legs, and how upright he holds himself!
sadness	"See, children, that is the way of the world," said the mother duck, whetting her beak, for she would have liked the eel's head herself.
anger	The ducklings did as they were bid, but the other duck stared, and said, "Look, here comes another brood, as if there were not enough of us already! and what a queer looking object one of them is; we don't want him here," and then one flew out and bit him in the neck.
disgust	"Yes, but he is so big and ugly," said the spiteful duck "and therefore he must be turned out."
disgust	"The others are very pretty children," said the old duck, with the rag on her leg, "all but that one; I wish his mother could improve him a little."
disgust	"That is impossible, your grace," replied the mother; "he is not pretty; but he has a very good disposition, and swims as well or even better than the others.
sadness	"He is too big," they all said, and the turkey cock, who had been born into the world with spurs, and fancied himself really an emperor, puffed himself out like a vessel in full sail, and flew at the duckling, and became quite red in the head with passion, so that the poor little thing did not know where to go, and was quite miserable because he was so ugly and laughed at by the whole farmyard.
disgust	The poor duckling was driven about by every one; even his brothers and sisters were unkind to him, and would say, "Ah, you ugly creature, I wish the cat would get you," and his mother said she wished he had never been born.
sadness	"They are afraid of me because I am ugly," he said.
sadness	Here he remained the whole night, feeling very tired and sorrowful.
surprise	"You are exceedingly ugly," said the wild ducks, "but that will not matter if you do not want to marry one of our family."
joy	After he had been on the moor two days, there came two wild geese, or rather goslings, for they had not been out of the egg long, and were very saucy.
joy	"Listen, friend," said one of them to the duckling, "you are so ugly, that we like you very well.
surprise	"Pop, pop," sounded in the air, and the two wild geese fell dead among the rushes, and the water was tinged with blood.
fear	How they terrified the poor duckling!
joy	He thrust his nose close to the duckling, showing his sharp teeth, and then, "splash, splash," he went into the water without touching him, "Oh," sighed the duckling, "how thankful I am for being so ugly; even a dog will not bite me."
fear	It was late in the day before all became quiet, but even then the poor young thing did not dare to move.
joy	She laid good eggs, and her mistress loved her as if she had been her own child.
surprise	"Oh what a prize!" she exclaimed, "I hope it is not a drake, for then I shall have some duck's eggs.
disgust	"Then you have no right to express an opinion when sensible people are speaking."
sadness	So the duckling sat in a corner, feeling very low spirited, till the sunshine and the fresh air came into the room through the open door, and then he began to feel such a great longing for a swim on the water, that he could not help telling the hen.
disgust	"What an absurd idea," said the hen.
disgust	"You have nothing else to do, therefore you have foolish fancies.
joy	"But it is so delightful to swim about on the water," said the duckling, "and so refreshing to feel it close over your head, while you dive down to the bottom."
disgust	"Delightful, indeed!" said the hen, "why you must be crazy!
disgust	Don't imagine such nonsense, child, and thank your good fortune that you have been received here.
disgust	But you are a chatterer, and your company is not very agreeable.
sadness	All this was very sad for the poor little duckling.
surprise	The duckling had never seen any like them before.
surprise	As they mounted higher and higher in the air, the ugly little duckling felt quite a strange sensation as he watched them.
fear	He whirled himself in the water like a wheel, stretched out his neck towards them, and uttered a cry so strange that it frightened himself.
joy	Could he ever forget those beautiful, happy birds; and when at last they were out of his sight, he dived under the water, and rose again almost beside himself with excitement.
fear	The warmth revived the poor little creature; but when the children wanted to play with him, the duckling thought they would do him some harm; so he started up in terror, fluttered into the milk-pan, and splashed the milk about the room.
fear	Then the woman clapped her hands, which frightened him still more.
sadness	The door stood open; the poor creature could just manage to slip out among the bushes, and lie down quite exhausted in the newly fallen snow.
sadness	It would be very sad, were I to relate all the misery and privations which the poor little duckling endured during the hard winter; but when it had passed, he found himself lying one morning in a moor, amongst the rushes.
sadness	The duckling remembered the lovely birds, and felt more strangely unhappy than ever.
sadness	"I will fly to those royal birds," he exclaimed, "and they will kill me, because I am so ugly, and dare to approach them; but it does not matter: better be killed by them than pecked by the ducks, beaten by the hens, pushed about by the maiden who feeds the poultry, or starved with hunger in the winter."
joy	The moment they espied the stranger, they rushed to meet him with outstretched wings.
sadness	"Kill me," said the poor bird; and he bent his head down to the surface of the water, and awaited death.
surprise	His own image; no longer a dark, gray bird, ugly and disagreeable to look at, but a graceful and beautiful swan.
joy	He now felt glad at having suffered sorrow and trouble, because it enabled him to enjoy so much better all the pleasure and happiness around him; for the great swans swam round the new-comer, and stroked his neck with their beaks, as a welcome.
joy	"See," cried the youngest, "there is a new one;" and the rest were delighted, and ran to their father and mother, dancing and clapping their hands, and shouting joyously, "There is another swan come; a new one has arrived."
joy	Then they threw more bread and cake into the water, and said, "The new one is the most beautiful of all; he is so young and pretty."
joy	Then he rustled his feathers, curved his slender neck, and cried joyfully, from the depths of his heart, "I never dreamed of such happiness as this, while I was an ugly duckling."
disgust	"Your 'something' is not enough for me," said the second brother; "what you talk of doing is nothing at all, it is journeyman's work, or might even be done by a machine.
disgust	No!
disgust	"I call it all nothing," said the third; "not in reality any position.
disgust	"Not in my opinion," said the fourth; "I will never follow the lead of others, and only imitate what they have done.
surprise	People said of this fifth brother, "There is something very precise about him; he has a good head-piece, but he does nothing."
surprise	The eldest brother, he who fabricated bricks, soon discovered that each brick, when finished, brought him in a small coin, if only a copper one; and many copper pieces, if placed one upon another, can be changed into a shining shilling; and at whatever door a person knocks, who has a number of these in his hands, whether it be the baker's, the butcher's, or the tailor's, the door flies open, and he can get all he wants.
joy	"While young, I can wander without a care, And build new houses everywhere; Fair and bright are my dreams of home, Always thought of wherever I roam.
joy	Hurrah for a workman's life of glee!
joy	It was really a pretty house, and in it were a happy pair.
joy	The flag of the corporation fluttered before it, and the journeymen and apprentices shouted "Hurrah."
disgust	"It is evidently for the sake of contrast that I and this wretched soul should arrive here exactly at the same time," said the critic.
anger	"In what manner did you leave the world?" he asked, just for the sake of saying something; for it made him feel very weary to stand there and wait.
surprise	"How I left the world?" she replied; "why, I can scarcely tell you.
fear	I lay looking at the cloud till I observed a little black spot in the middle of it, which gradually grew larger and larger, and then I knew what it meant- I am old and experienced; and although this token is not often seen, I knew it, and a shuddering seized me.
joy	Twice in my life had I seen this same thing, and I knew that there would be an awful storm, with a spring tide, which would overwhelm the poor people who were now out on the ice, drinking, dancing, and making merry.
fear	I was so alarmed, that I felt more strength and life than I had done for some time.
joy	I saw the people outside running and jumping about on the ice; I saw the beautiful flags waving in the wind; I heard the boys shouting, 'Hurrah!' and the lads and lasses singing, and everything full of merriment and joy.
fear	I cried out as loudly as I could, but no one heard me; I was too far off from the people.
fear	Soon would the storm burst, the ice break, and all who were on it be irretrievably lost.
sadness	They could not hear me, and to go to them was quite out of my power.
sadness	Oh, if I could only get them safe on land!
sadness	I escaped fortunately as far as the threshold of the door; but there I fell down and remained: I could go no farther.
sadness	The flames rushed out towards me, flickered on the window, and rose high above the roof.
fear	The people on the ice became aware of the fire, and ran as fast as possible to help a poor sick woman, who, as they thought, was being burnt to death.
joy	But the people had reached the sea-wall, where the sparks were flying round.
joy	I had saved them all; but I suppose I could not survive the cold and fright; so I came up here to the gates of paradise.
joy	"See," said the angel, pointing to the wonderful straw, "this is what the poor woman has brought.
disgust	I know thou hast accomplished nothing, not even made a single brick.
disgust	But thou canst not return to earth, and I can do nothing for thee."
fear	She said, "His brother made all the stone and bricks, and sent them to me to build my poor little dwelling, which was a great deal to do for a poor woman like me.
fear	Could not all these bricks and pieces be as a wall of stone to prevail for him?
sadness	It was the hour of the mother's sorrow, when there pealed forth from the church tower the sound of festive bells.
joy	In that solemn hour the sweet and joyous chiming filled the hearts of those in the humble dwelling with thankfulness and trust; and when, amidst these joyous sounds, a little son was born to them, the words of prayer and praise arose from their overflowing hearts, and their happiness seemed to ring out over town and country in the liquid tones of the church bells' chime.
joy	The little one, with its bright eyes and golden hair, had been welcomed joyously on that dark November day.
joy	Its parents kissed it lovingly, and the father wrote these words in the Bible, "On the tenth of November, 1759, God sent us a son."
sadness	He and his sister, two years older than himself, had often wept scalding tears over the story of Him who suffered death on the cross for us all.
joy	His mother also told him how the chiming of that old bell had once filled her heart with joy and confidence, and that in the midst of the sweet tones her child had been given to her.
joy	He bowed his head over it and kissed it, old, thrown away, and cracked as it was, and standing there amidst the grass and nettles.
sadness	A record of this bright display will live in the memory of man, for through it the pupil in the military school was in tears and sorrow.
sadness	Dark days and cold nights also passed over the old bell, and it noticed them not; but the bell in the man's heart felt it to be a gloomy time.
joy	An old maid stood at the window; she had hung chickweed over the cage, and the little linnet which it contained hopped from perch to perch and sang and twittered merrily.
joy	"Yes, it's all very well for you to sing," said the bottle neck: that is, he did not really speak the words as we do, for the neck of a bottle cannot speak; but he thought them to himself in his own mind, just as people sometimes talk quietly to themselves.
disgust	"Yes, you may sing very well, you have all your limbs uninjured; you should feel what it is like to lose your body, and only have a neck and a mouth left, with a cork stuck in it, as I have: you wouldn't sing then, I know.
sadness	I have no reason to sing, nor could I sing now if I were ever so happy; but when I was a whole bottle, and they rubbed me with a cork, didn't I sing then?
joy	The little bird sang his own song merrily; in the street below there was driving and running to and fro, every one thought of his own affairs, or perhaps of nothing at all; but the bottle neck thought deeply.
surprise	The bottle did not behold the light of day again, until it was unpacked with the rest in the wine merchant's cellar, and, for the first time, rinsed with water, which caused some very curious sensations.
joy	"Ah, how beautiful is life."
joy	All these tones of joy and song in the bottle were like the working of a young poet's brain, who often knows not the meaning of the tones which are sounding within him.
joy	She was young and pretty; her brown eyes laughed, and a smile lingered round her mouth as sweet as that in her eyes.
sadness	There had been a great deal of talk on this subject while the basket was being packed, and during this conversation the eyes and the mouth of the furrier's daughter did not wear a very joyful expression.
joy	It remained there a long time; but when at last it was brought forth it appeared as if something pleasant had happened, for every one was laughing; the furrier's daughter laughed too, but she said very little, and her cheeks were like two roses.
surprise	What a strange sensation it was to have the cork drawn for the first time!
joy	"Long life to the betrothed," cried the papa, and every glass was emptied to the dregs, while the young sailor kissed his beautiful bride.
joy	"Happiness and blessing to you both," said the old people-father and mother, and the young man filled the glasses again.
joy	"Safe return, and a wedding this day next year," he cried; and when the glasses were empty he took the bottle, raised it on high, and said, "Thou hast been present here on the happiest day of my life; thou shalt never be used by others!"
disgust	"I gave them wine, and they gave me muddy water," he had said to himself, "but I suppose it was all well meant."
joy	He could no longer see the betrothed couple, nor the cheerful old people; but for a long time he could hear them rejoicing and singing.
joy	Those were happy days, and the bottle would sing when rubbed with a cork, and it was called a great lark," "Peter Jensen's lark."
sadness	At the last moment, when the ship was sinking, the young mate wrote on a piece of paper, "We are going down: God's will be done."
surprise	"What trouble they have taken with that bottle over yonder!" said one, and very likely it is broken after all."
surprise	But the bottle was not broken, and, better still, it understood every word that was said: this language it had heard at the furnaces and at the wine merchant's; in the forest and on the ship,- it was the only good old language it could understand.
joy	It had returned home, and the language was as a welcome greeting.
joy	For very joy, it felt ready to jump out of people's hands, and scarcely noticed that its cork had been drawn, and its contents emptied out, till it found itself carried to a cellar, to be left there and forgotten.
joy	"There's no place like home, even if it's a cellar."
joy	It never occurred to him to think that he might lie there for years, he felt so comfortable.
joy	The stars twinkled; and the new moon, in the form of a crescent, was surrounded by the shadowy disc of the whole moon, and looked like a gray globe with a golden rim: it was a beautiful sight for those who had good eyes.
joy	Everything here appeared lovely to our bottle, for it was again in the green wood, amid joy and feasting; again it heard music and song, and the noise and murmur of a crowd, especially in that part of the garden where the lamps blazed, and the paper lanterns displayed their brilliant colors.
joy	It stood in a distant walk certainly, but a place pleasant for contemplation; and it carried a light; and was at once useful and ornamental.
joy	It seemed to the bottle as if he were living that time over again.
joy	Not only the guests but other people were walking in the garden, who were allowed to witness the splendor and the festivities.
joy	She was thinking, like the bottle, of the green wood, and of a young betrothed pair, who were closely connected with herself; she was thinking of that hour, the happiest of her life, in which she had taken part, when she had herself been one of that betrothed pair; such hours are never to be forgotten, let a maiden be as old as she may.
joy	The rabbit was quite excited because he knew that he was to be taken up, and let down again in a parachute.
joy	Then the ropes which held it were cut through, and the aerial ship rose in the air with the aeronaut and the basket containing the bottle and the rabbit, while the music sounded and all the people shouted "Hurrah."
joy	"This is a wonderful journey up into the air," thought the bottle; "it is a new way of sailing, and here, at least, there is no fear of striking against anything."
surprise	Then it began to descend much more rapidly than the rabbit had done, made somersaults in the air, and felt itself quite young and unfettered, although it was half full of wine.
joy	Then they hung it in the cage of the little bird, who sang and twittered more merrily than ever.
joy	Do you see how splendidly the tree has grown?
sadness	It has been raised from only a little sprig of myrtle that you gave me on the day after my betrothal, and from which I was to make my own bridal bouquet when a year had passed: but that day never came; the eyes were closed which were to have been my light and joy through life.
joy	Before the sprig you gave me faded, I took a spray, and planted it in the earth; and now, as you see, it has become a large tree, and a bunch of the blossoms shall at last appear at a wedding festival, in the bouquet of your daughter."
joy	At the window of one of them sat a little boy with fresh rosy cheeks, and clear sparkling eyes, who was very fond of the old house, in sunshine or in moonlight.
joy	Certainly it was a very good house to look at for amusement.
sadness	The little boy one day heard his parents say, "The old man opposite is very well off, but is terribly lonely."
joy	And the old attendant nodded and looked very pleased, and then he carried the tin soldier into the house.
disgust	Oh dear, how I am creaking.
disgust	Gout in my back, ugh."
joy	"Thank you for the tin soldier my little friend," said the old man, "and thank you also for coming to see me."
joy	"Thanks, thanks," or "Creak, creak," said all the furniture.
joy	"Oh," replied the old man, "I have pleasant thoughts of all that has passed, recalled by memory; and now you are come to visit me, and that is very pleasant."
joy	It was very pleasant, certainly, to be in that old house.
sadness	"I cannot endure it," said the tin soldier, who stood on a shelf, "it is so lonely and dull here.
sadness	I have been accustomed to live in a family, and I cannot get used to this life.
sadness	I cannot bear it.
joy	It is not here like it was in your house opposite, when your father and mother talked so cheerfully together, while you and all the dear children made such a delightful noise.
sadness	No, it is all lonely in the old man's house.
sadness	Oh, I cannot bear it."
sadness	"Ah, but I never see any, and I don't know them," said the tin soldier, "and I cannot bear it."
joy	Then the old man came back with a pleasant face; and brought with him beautiful preserved fruits, as well as apples and nuts; and the little boy thought no more of the tin soldier.
joy	How happy and delighted the little boy was; and after he returned home, and while days and weeks passed, a great deal of nodding took place from one house to the other, and then the little boy went to pay another visit.
sadness	"I cannot bear it any longer," said the tin soldier; "I have wept tears of tin, it is so melancholy here.
sadness	Let me go to the wars, and lose an arm or a leg, that would be some change; I cannot bear it.
sadness	I have had visits from mine, and you may believe me it is not altogether pleasant.
joy	You all stood looking very grave, although it was very difficult to do so, but I laughed so to myself that I fell down from the table, and got a bruise, which is there still; I know it was not right to laugh.
sadness	Ah, really he must be very happy; I cannot endure this life."
joy	Then he looked at the picture he had bought at the broker's, and his eyes sparkled brightly as he nodded at it, and said, "Ah, she could sing that tune."
sadness	"I will go to the wars!
sadness	I will go to the wars!" cried the tin soldier as loud as he could, and threw himself down on the floor.
surprise	And indeed nobody was home, for the old man was dead.
sadness	He was to be taken to the country to be buried there in his own grave; so they carried him away; no one followed him, for all his friends were dead; and the little boy kissed his hand to the coffin as the hearse moved away with it.
joy	The sparrows assembled in dozens upon the wild vines, and chattered all together as loud as they could, but not about the old house; none of them could remember it, for many years had passed by, so many indeed, that the little boy was now a man, and a really good man too, and his parents were very proud of him.
joy	He was just married, and had come, with his young wife, to reside in the new house with the garden in front of it, and now he stood there by her side while she planted a field flower that she thought very pretty.
surprise	"Oh dear, what was that?" she exclaimed, as something pricked her.
surprise	It was- only think!- it was really the tin soldier, the very same which had been lost up in the old man's room, and had been hidden among old wood and rubbish for a long time, till it sunk into the earth, where it must have been for many years.
joy	And the tin soldier felt as if he was recovering from a fainting fit.
joy	"Let me see him," said the young man, and then he smiled and shook his head, and said, "It can scarcely be the same, but it reminds me of something that happened to one of my tin soldiers when I was a little boy."
sadness	"Oh, how dreadfully lonely he must have been," said she.
joy	"Yes, terribly lonely," cried the tin soldier; "still it is delightful not to be forgotten."
joy	The emperor ordered them to be carried into the great hall where the princess was just playing "Visitors are coming" with her ladies-in-waiting; when she saw the large cases with the presents therein, she clapped her hands for joy.
joy	"Oh, how nicely it is made," exclaimed the ladies.
joy	"It is more than nice," said the emperor, "it is charming."
surprise	"For shame, pa," she said, "it is not artificial, it is natural!"
disgust	"For shame, it is natural" repeated all her ladies.
joy	"Superbe, charmant," said the ladies of the court, for they all prattled French, one worse than the other.
sadness	"You are right," said the emperor, and began to cry like a little child.
joy	But the prince was not discouraged.
joy	When the princess with her ladies passed by and heard the tune, she stopped and looked quite pleased, for she also could play it- in fact, it was the only tune she could play, and she played it with one finger.
joy	"That is the tune I know," she exclaimed.
disgust	"God forbid," said the lady.
disgust	"It is very naughty," said the princess, and walked off.
disgust	"That is tiresome," said the princess.
joy	That was a pleasure!
joy	The ladies danced and clapped their hands for joy.
joy	"But that is superbe," said the princess passing by.
joy	"I have never heard a more beautiful composition.
disgust	"I believe he is mad," said the princess, and walked off, but soon she stopped.
disgust	"But we do not like to kiss him" said the ladies.
disgust	"The ladies of the court are up to some mischief, I think.
surprise	"What does this mean?" he said, when he saw that his daughter was kissing the swineherd, and then hit their heads with his shoe just as the swineherd received the sixty-eighth kiss.
anger	"Go out of my sight," said the emperor, for he was very angry; and both the princess and the swineherd were banished from the empire.
sadness	There she stood and cried, the swineherd scolded her, and the rain came down in torrents.
sadness	"Alas, unfortunate creature that I am!" said the princess, "I wish I had accepted the prince.
sadness	Oh, how wretched I am!"
anger	"I have now learnt to despise you," he said.
disgust	"You refused an honest prince; you did not appreciate the rose and the nightingale; but you did not mind kissing a swineherd for his toys; you have no one but yourself to blame!"
joy	And then she can tell the most wonderful stories.
joy	She has a hymn-book with large silver clasps, in which she often reads; and in the book, between the leaves, lies a rose, quite flat and dry; it is not so pretty as the roses which are standing in the glass, and yet she smiles at it most pleasantly, and tears even come into her eyes.
joy	Why, when grandmother's tears fall upon the rose, and she is looking at it, the rose revives, and fills the room with its fragrance; the walls vanish as in a mist, and all around her is the glorious green wood, where in summer the sunlight streams through thick foliage; and grandmother, why she is young again, a charming maiden, fresh as a rose, with round, rosy cheeks, fair, bright ringlets, and a figure pretty and graceful; but the eyes, those mild, saintly eyes, are the same,- they have been left to grandmother.
joy	At her side sits a young man, tall and strong; he gives her a rose and she smiles.
sadness	Grandmother cannot smile like that now.
joy	We could hear her gentle breathing as she slept; gradually it became quieter and calmer, and on her countenance beamed happiness and peace.
joy	It was as if lighted up with a ray of sunshine.
joy	She smiled once more, and then people said she was dead.
joy	She was laid in a black coffin, looking mild and beautiful in the white folds of the shrouded linen, though her eyes were closed; but every wrinkle had vanished, her hair looked white and silvery, and around her mouth lingered a sweet smile.
joy	They are better off than we are; the dead return no more.
joy	But over the grave fresh roses bloom, the nightingale sings, and the organ sounds and there still lives a remembrance of old grandmother, with the loving, gentle eyes that always looked young.
surprise	It is quite a picture to see a half-naked boy clasping the well-formed creature by the head, as he presses his rosy lips against its jaws.
sadness	In the garden of the grand duke's palace, under the roof of one of the wings, where a thousand roses bloom in winter, a little ragged boy had been sitting the whole day long; a boy, who might serve as a type of Italy, lovely and smiling, and yet still suffering.
sadness	He was hungry and thirsty, yet no one gave him anything; and when it became dark, and they were about to close the gardens, the porter turned him out.
surprise	The Metal Pig raised himself gently, and the boy heard him say quite distinctly, "Hold tight, little boy, for I am going to run;" and away he started for a most wonderful ride.
fear	The metallic groups of figures, among which were Perseus and the Rape of the Sabines, looked like living persons, and cries of terror sounded from them all across the noble square.
joy	The little boy said not a word; he was half pleased and half afraid.
joy	But the grandest appeared when the door of a side room opened; the little boy could remember what beautiful things he had seen there, but to-night everything shone in its brightest colors.
joy	As they passed from hall to hall, beauty everywhere showed itself; and as the Metal Pig went step by step from one picture to the other, the little boy could see it all plainly.
joy	One glory eclipsed another; yet there was one picture that fixed itself on the little boy's memory, more especially because of the happy children it represented, for these the little boy had seen in daylight.
joy	The Florentine, Angiolo Bronzino, painted this picture; most beautiful is the expression on the face of the two children, who appear to have full confidence that they shall reach heaven at last.
joy	They are embracing each other, and one little one stretches out his hand towards another who stands below him, and points to himself, as if he were saying, "I am going to heaven."
joy	The older people stand as if uncertain, yet hopeful, and they bow in humble adoration to the Lord Jesus.
joy	The boy raised his hands towards the smiling children, and then the Pig ran off with him through the open vestibule.
joy	"Thank you, thank you, you beautiful animal," said the little boy, caressing the Metal Pig as it ran down the steps.
joy	"Thanks to yourself also," replied the Metal Pig; "I have helped you and you have helped me, for it is only when I have an innocent child on my back that I receive the power to run.
sadness	Yes; as you see, I can even venture under the rays of the lamp, in front of the picture of the Madonna, but I may not enter the church; still from without, and while you are upon my back, I may look in through the open door.
fear	Do not get down yet, for if you do, then I shall be lifeless, as you have seen me in the Porta Rosa."
joy	"I will stay with you, my dear creature," said the little boy.
surprise	The boy stretched forth his hands towards the light, and at the same moment the Metal Pig started again so rapidly that he was obliged to cling tightly to him.
surprise	The wind whistled in his ears, he heard the church door creak on its hinges as it closed, and it seemed to him as if he had lost his senses- then a cold shudder passed over him, and he awoke.
fear	Fear and trembling came upon him as he thought of his mother; she had sent him out the day before to get some money, he had not done so, and now he was hungry and thirsty.
sadness	Once more he clasped the neck of his metal horse, kissed its nose, and nodded farewell to it.
surprise	Another broken-down staircase led from the gallery, and two Russian sailors running down it almost upset the poor boy.
fear	"Don't be angry," he pleaded; "I received nothing, I have nothing at all;" and he seized his mother's dress and would have kissed it.
surprise	This pot she took in her lap, warmed her fingers, and pushed the boy with her elbow.
anger	"Certainly you must have some money," she said.
sadness	The boy began to cry, and then she struck him with her foot till he cried out louder.
disgust	"Felicita," she said, "what are you doing to the child?"
anger	"The child is mine," she answered; "I can murder him if I like, and you too, Giannina."
anger	And then she swung about the fire-pot.
fear	The boy rushed out at the sight, sped across the courtyard, and fled from the house.
sadness	Here everything was bright, and the boy knelt down by the first tomb on his right, the grave of Michael Angelo, and sobbed as if his heart would break.
sadness	Hunger and thirst overpowered the child, and he became quite faint and ill.
joy	A little white poodle, so closely shaven that his pink skin could plainly be seen, frisked about the room, and gambolled upon the boy.
joy	"Innocent souls are soon intimate," said the woman, as she caressed both the boy and the dog.
joy	These good people gave the child food and drink, and said he should stay with them all night, and that the next day the old man, who was called Giuseppe, would go and speak to his mother.
joy	A little homely bed was prepared for him, but to him who had so often slept on the hard stones it was a royal couch, and he slept sweetly and dreamed of the splendid pictures and of the Metal Pig.
sadness	He wept at the thought, and then he played with the little, lively dog, and kissed it, while the old woman looked kindly at him to encourage him.
joy	Then she said, "He is a good lad, he shall stay with us, he may become a clever glovemaker, like you.
joy	So the boy stayed with them, and the woman herself taught him to sew; and he ate well, and slept well, and became very merry.
surprise	Suddenly he fancied he heard feet outside going pit-a-pat.
sadness	But there was nothing to be seen; whatever he had heard had passed already.
joy	They stopped before the picture by Bronzino, in which Christ is represented as standing in the lower world, with the children smiling before Him, in the sweet expectation of entering heaven; and the poor boy smiled, too, for here was his heaven.
anger	"Why don't you go?" said the painter.
joy	"You happy creature," he said; "how I have longed for you! we must take a ride to-night."
surprise	But the Metal Pig lay motionless, while the fresh stream gushed forth from its mouth.
surprise	He looked down, and there was Bellissima, little smooth-shaven Bellissima, barking as if she would have said, "Here I am too; why are you sitting there?"
fear	A fiery dragon could not have frightened the little boy so much as did the little dog in this place.
surprise	"Bellissima in the street, and not dressed!" as the old lady called it; "what would be the end of this?"
sadness	The poor little thing trembled so with cold, that the boy ran homeward as fast as he could.
surprise	"Where have you stolen that pretty dog?" they asked; and they took it away from him.
fear	The boy did not know whether he had better jump into the Arno, or go home and confess everything.
fear	They would certainly kill him, he thought.
fear	"Bellissima in the watch-house!" she cried.
anger	"You bad boy! how did you entice her out?
fear	Poor little delicate thing, with those rough policemen! and she'll be frozen with cold."
sadness	Giuseppe went off at once, while his wife lamented, and the boy wept.
anger	The painter, however, consoled the little fellow, and tried to soften the lady's anger; but she would not be pacified till her husband returned with Bellissima, who had been with the police.
joy	Then there was great rejoicing, and the painter caressed the boy, and gave him a number of pictures.
joy	Oh, what beautiful pictures these were!- figures with funny heads; and, above all, the Metal Pig was there too.
joy	Oh, nothing could be more delightful.
joy	The first leisure moment during the next day, the boy got a pencil, and on the back of one of the other drawings he attempted to copy the drawing of the Metal Pig, and he succeeded.
joy	Certainly it was rather crooked, rather up and down, one leg thick, and another thin; still it was like the copy, and he was overjoyed at what he had done.
joy	A second pig was drawn by the side of the first, and this looked a hundred times better; and the third attempt was so good, that everybody might know what it was meant to represent.
joy	His collection of pictures increased; but as yet they were only copies of lifeless objects, when one day Bellissima came gambolling before him: "Stand still," cried he, "and I will draw you beautifully, to put amongst my collection."
anger	He tied her head and tail; but she barked and jumped, and so pulled and tightened the string, that she was nearly strangled; and just then her mistress walked in.
anger	"You wicked boy! the poor little creature!" was all she could utter.
anger	She pushed the boy from her, thrust him away with her foot, called him a most ungrateful, good-for-nothing, wicked boy, and forbade him to enter the house again.
sadness	A large gilt frame surrounded it, and on one corner of the frame a laurel wreath had been hung; but a black band, twined unseen among the green leaves, and a streamer of crape, hung down from it; for within the last few days the young artist had- died.
sadness	Fortunately she scrambled out of the bucket; but she fell into the water with a terrible flop, and had to lie sick for three days with pains in her back.
disgust	"She's thick, and fat and ugly," said the young green Frogs; "and her children will be just as ugly as she is."
disgust	The young frogs listened and stared; and as these words did not please them, they made grimaces and dived down under the water.
joy	"Oh, it is such a splendid and precious thing, that I cannot describe it," said the Mother-Toad.
disgust	"Quack!" said the little Toad; and that's just as if one of us were to say, "Aha!"
disgust	"You're the ugliest thing I've seen for one while."
joy	"It's much nicer here than down in the well!
joy	I should like to stay here my whole life long!" said the little Toad.
joy	"It's almost too much of a good thing here; it tickles one so."
joy	"It's a glorious thing to live! glorious to get out of the well, and to lie among the stinging-nettles, and to crawl along the dusty road.
joy	"It will be too damp for you here," said the Frogs; "but you are very welcome!
joy	But it doesn't matter; you are equally welcome."
anger	I must get higher yet; I feel a great restlessness and longing."
surprise	How great it is! how bright it is!
surprise	Oh, how it seems to shine in my head!
joy	But I haven't the jewel; not that I cry about that- no, I must go higher up, into splendor and joy!
fear	I feel so confident, and yet I am afraid.
fear	It's a difficult step to take, and yet it must be taken.
joy	Onward, therefore, straight onward!"
surprise	"What a number of different creatures there are that I never knew! and how beautiful and great the world is!
surprise	"How green it is here! how beautiful it is here!"
disgust	It hides half the world from me, but I don't care for the world."
disgust	"It doesn't do that with a good will," thought the Fowl, and lifted up her head to peck at the Caterpillar.
fear	The Toad was so horrified at this, that she came crawling straight up towards the Fowl.
surprise	"Aha, it has allies," quoth the Fowl.
disgust	"Just look at the crawling thing!"
disgust	"I don't care for the little green morsel; it would only tickle my throat."
joy	"I writhed myself free," said the Caterpillar.
joy	"What a good thing it is when one has presence of mind!
sadness	And the little Toad came up and expressed her sympathy.
joy	She was glad that in her ugliness she had frightened the fowls.
joy	Nothing is so beautiful as property.
joy	"Yes, higher up," said the little Toad; "higher-up!
surprise	"How high up they live!" thought the Toad.
surprise	"If one could only get as high as that!"
joy	"But it's so wonderfully ugly," persisted the first.
surprise	"A jewel!" cried the naturalist.
joy	"What a good thing that I have not got it!
disgust	"Man is the most conceited creature!" said the Stork.
disgust	"Listen how their jaws are wagging; and for all that they can't clap properly.
disgust	They boast of their gifts of eloquence and their language!
disgust	It makes my beak turn cold when I think of it.
disgust	The world could get on without men.
surprise	"What a great man that is yonder! and how high he sits!
surprise	Higher than ever I saw any one sit yet; and how he can swim!" she cried, as the Stork soared away through the air with outspread pinions.
joy	"I must go to Egypt!" said she.
joy	"If the Stork or one of his young ones would only take me!
joy	Yes, I shall get to Egypt, for I feel so happy!
joy	All the longing and all the pleasure that I feel is much better than having a jewel in one's head."
joy	The Stork's beak pinched her, and the wind whistled; it was not exactly agreeable, but she was going upward- upward towards Egypt- and she knew it; and that was why her eyes gleamed, and a spark seemed to fly out of them.
surprise	"Quunk!- ah!"
joy	WE are in a rich, happy house, where the master, the servants, the friends of the family are full of joy and felicity.
joy	For on this day a son and heir has been born, and mother and child are doing well.
joy	Everything invited to slumber, everything had a charming look of repose; and so the nurse had discovered, for she slept; and well she might sleep, while everything around her told of happiness and blessing.
joy	"Everything has been bestowed here," said the guardian angel.
disgust	"Wanting!" cried the guardian angel; "nothing must be wanting here; and if it is so, let us fetch it; let us seek the powerful fairy; let us go to her."
anger	"Her pearl must not be missing; it must be there, that the crown, when worn, may be complete.
sadness	Tears of sorrow rolled down their cheeks, and fell in heavy drops on the floor, but not a word was spoken.
sadness	The silence which reigned here expressed a world of grief.
sadness	With silent steps, still sobbing, they left the room.
sadness	Strange men came in and placed the lid of the coffin over the dead, and drove the nails firmly in; while the blows of the hammer resounded through the house, and echoed in the hearts that were bleeding.
fear	"Whither art thou leading me?" asked the guardian angel.
sadness	A hot tear rolled into her lap, and formed itself into a pearl, glowing with all the colors of the rainbow.
joy	At times the snow would be piled so high around our hut as almost to hide it, and then my mother appeared most cheerful.
joy	She would hold my head between her hands, and sing the songs she never sang at other times, for the Turks, our masters, would not allow it.
disgust	And the stag answered, 'The Turk has come to our city; he has wild dogs for the chase, a goodly pack.' 'I will drive them away across the islands!' cried the young roebuck; 'I will drive them away across the islands into the deep sea.'
sadness	And when my mother sang thus, her eyes would become moist; and on the long eyelashes were tears, but she concealed them and watched the black bread baking in the ashes.
anger	Then I would clench my fist, and cry, "We will kill these Turks!"
surprise	Soon after, we heard the sound of firing.
sadness	I saw my poor dead father, and cried till I fell asleep.
surprise	When I awoke, I found myself in a prison; but the room was not worse than our own in the hut.
joy	The music sounded, and the people left the church hand-in-hand, with joy and gladness.
surprise	They were the same stars, and in the same position over me as when I used to sit in front of our hut at Delphi, and I had almost begun to fancy I was still there, when suddenly there was a splash in the water- Anastasia had fallen in; but in a moment Aphtanides has sprung in after her, and was now holding her up to me.
fear	We dried her clothes as well as we were able, and remained on the water till they were dry; for we did not wish it to be known what a fright we had had, nor the danger which our little adopted sister had incurred, in whose life Aphtanides had now a part.
joy	How peaceful and silent it was as we walked on through the thick, wild thyme, still fragrant, though the sun had scorched the leaves.
fear	My mother lighted a fire, and roasted some roots she had brought with her, and I and my little sister slept among the bushes, without fear of the ugly smidraki, from whose throat issues fire, or of the wolf and the jackal; for my mother sat by us, and I considered her presence sufficient protection.
joy	He said he had been longing to see us so much; and he remained with us two whole happy days.
surprise	"How much you know!"
surprise	I exclaimed, "and what wonders you can relate?"
joy	"I think what you once told me, the finest of all," he replied; "you told me of a thing that has never been out of my thoughts- of the good old custom of 'the bond of friendship,'- a custom I should like to follow.
joy	Brother, let you and I go to church, as your father and Anastasia's father once did.
joy	Your sister Anastasia is the most beautiful and most innocent of maidens, and she shall consecrate the deed.
joy	Anastasia blushed like a young rose, and my mother kissed Aphtanides.
joy	Then she joined out hands and kissed us on the forehead, and we again prayed silently.
fear	I saw it, I understood the cause, and I believe my hand trembled too.
sadness	"And she shall be thine," he exclaimed; "thine!
sadness	I also love her, but tomorrow I depart.
sadness	She looked at Aphtanides with a sweet but mournful expression on her face.
sadness	"To-morrow you are going to leave us," she said.
sadness	"I am very sorry."
sadness	"Sorry!" he exclaimed, and his voice was troubled with a grief as deep as my own.
joy	I threw my arms round her, and pressed my lips to hers.
sadness	Many of them were very aged; lonely old boys, with strange thoughts and eccentric habits.
fear	If even a tiny spark had remained it might set fire to something, and cause great damage.
fear	But often, when he had got half way back, he would fancy the iron shutters of the door were not properly fastened, and his thin legs would carry him down again.
sadness	And when at last he crept into bed, he would be so cold that his teeth chattered in his head.
sadness	But this was scarcely an agreeable entertainment; for thoughts of olden memories raise the curtains from the past, and sometimes pierce the heart with painful recollections till the agony brings tears to the waking eyes.
sadness	And so it was with Anthony; often the scalding tears, like pearly drops, would fall from his eyes to the coverlet and roll on the floor with a sound as if one of his heartstrings had broken.
sadness	If he dried his eyes with his nightcap, then the tear and the picture would be crushed; but the source of the tears remained and welled up again in his heart.
sadness	The pictures did not follow one another in order, as the circumstances they represented had occurred; very often the most painful would come together, and when those came which were most full of joy, they had always the deepest shadow thrown upon them.
sadness	How vividly were represented to him, in a glittering tear that rolled down his cheek, two children at play- a boy and a girl.
joy	Then they got a flower-pot, filled it with earth, and were soon both very busy and eager about it.
joy	"They are Molly and me," said the boy.
joy	"How wonderful they are, and so beautiful!"
sadness	And all this about the two children was mirrored to old Anthony in a single tear, which could soon be wiped away and disappear, but might come again from its source in the heart of the old man.
joy	"I may kiss him," she would say proudly, as she threw her arms round his neck; she was vain of her power over Anthony, for he would submit quietly and think nothing of it.
sadness	And Molly and Anthony both wept, but these tears all flowed together into one tear which had the rosy shimmer of joy.
joy	Molly had told him that she loved him- loved him more than all the splendors of Weimar.
sadness	One, two, three years went by, and during the whole time he received only two letters.
joy	One stanza pleased him exceedingly-
joy	"Through the forest, and in the vale, Sweetly warbles the nightingale.
joy	He was received with a hearty welcome, and introduced to plenty of grand and pleasant company, where overflowing winecups were passed about.
sadness	Anthony also said, "Farewell."
sadness	Not a tear came into his eye; he felt he was no longer Molly's friend.
anger	Hot iron and cold iron alike take the skin from our lips, and we feel the same sensation if we kiss either; and Anthony's kiss was now the kiss of hatred, as it had once been the kiss of love.
sadness	"What matters it?" said he; "I am ruined also.
anger	I will destroy everything that can remind me of her, or of Lady Halle, or Lady Venus, the heathen woman.
anger	I will break down the apple-tree, and tear it up by the roots; never more shall it blossom or bear fruit."
sadness	Dark days, heavy trials, with poverty at the door, came rolling into the house upon them like the waves of the sea.
sadness	Sorrow and suffering deprived Anthony's father of his strength, so that he had something else to think of besides nursing his love-sorrows and his anger against Molly.
surprise	How different the world, and the people in it, appeared to Anthony now, to what he had thought in his childhood!
joy	At times he would think in this way; yet again and again the songs would sound in his soul, and his heart become gentle and pious.
joy	"God's will is the best," he would then say.
joy	All has happened for the best.
disgust	She could not help it, and yet I have been so bitter, and in such enmity against her."
sadness	How much came back to his remembrance as he looked through the tears once more on his native town!
joy	"That flourishes still," said he, as he gazed.
disgust	"The blossoms are often plucked," said Anthony; "the fruit is stolen and the branches broken without a thankful thought of their profusion and beauty.
disgust	Forsaken and forgotten, in a garden by a hedge in a field, and close to a public road.
disgust	There it stands, unsheltered, plundered, and broken.
sadness	It certainly has not yet withered; but in the course of years the number of blossoms from time to time will grow less, and at last it was cease altogether to bear fruit; and then its history will be over."
sadness	"Marry! ha, ha!" and he laughed bitterly to himself at the thought.
sadness	There lay the old bachelor, forsaken by all, and unable to help himself.
joy	A little spider, which he could however not see, busily and cheerfully spun its web above him, so that there should be a kind of little banner waving over the old man, when his eyes closed.
joy	The recollection of her pious deeds was as light to the soul of poor Anthony.
fear	He remembered a story told of her, that on one occasion, when she was carrying a basket full of wine and provisions, her husband, who had watched her footsteps, stepped forward and asked her angrily what she carried in her basket, whereupon, with fear and trembling, she answered, "Roses, which I have plucked from the garden."
surprise	Then he tore away the cloth which covered the basket, and what could equal the surprise of the pious woman, to find that by a miracle, everything in her basket- the wine, the bread- had all been changed into roses.
joy	In this way the memory of the kind lady dwelt in the calm mind of Anthony.
joy	He saw the branches of an apple-tree spreading above him.
joy	The fragrant leaves of the tree fell upon him and cooled his burning brow; upon his parched lips they seemed like refreshing bread and wine; and as they rested on his breast, a peaceful calm stole over him, and he felt inclined to sleep.
joy	Glorious! wonderful!
joy	That apple-tree, planted in love, now appears before me in heavenly beauty."
surprise	"Hallo! how the nightcap burns!" he exclaimed, as he tore it from his bead.
joy	The great city where he resided was very gay; every day many strangers from all parts of the globe arrived.
surprise	"That must be wonderful cloth," thought the emperor.
joy	"If I were to be dressed in a suit made of this cloth I should be able to find out which men in my empire were unfit for their places, and I could distinguish the clever from the stupid.
joy	I must have this cloth woven for me without delay."
joy	"I should very much like to know how they are getting on with the cloth," thought the emperor.
fear	But he felt rather uneasy when he remembered that he who was not fit for his office could not see it.
fear	Personally, he was of opinion that he had nothing to fear, yet he thought it advisable to send somebody else first to see how matters stood.
fear	Everybody in the town knew what a remarkable quality the stuff possessed, and all were anxious to see how bad or stupid their neighbours were.
surprise	"Heaven preserve us!" he thought, and opened his eyes wide, "I cannot see anything at all," but he did not say so.
surprise	The poor old minister tried his very best, but he could see nothing, for there was nothing to be seen.
fear	"Oh dear," he thought, "can I be so stupid?
fear	I should never have thought so, and nobody must know it!
fear	Is it possible that I am not fit for my office?
fear	No, no, I cannot say that I was unable to see the cloth."
joy	"Oh, it is very pretty, exceedingly beautiful," replied the old minister looking through his glasses.
joy	"What a beautiful pattern, what brilliant colours!
joy	I shall tell the emperor that I like the cloth very much."
joy	"We are pleased to hear that," said the two weavers, and described to him the colours and explained the curious pattern.
joy	"Is it not a beautiful piece of cloth?" asked the two swindlers, showing and explaining the magnificent pattern, which, however, did not exist.
disgust	"I am not stupid," said the man.
sadness	"It is therefore my good appointment for which I am not fit.
joy	It is very strange, but I must not let any one know it;" and he praised the cloth, which he did not see, and expressed his joy at the beautiful colours and the fine pattern.
joy	"It is very excellent," he said to the emperor.
joy	"Is it not magnificent?" said the two old statesmen who had been there before.
surprise	"What is this?" thought the emperor, "I do not see anything at all.
joy	"Really," he said, turning to the weavers, "your cloth has our most gracious approval;" and nodding contentedly he looked at the empty loom, for he did not like to say that he saw nothing.
joy	"It is magnificent, beautiful, excellent," one heard them say; everybody seemed to be delighted, and the emperor appointed the two swindlers "Imperial Court weavers."
joy	The emperor and all his barons then came to the hall; the swindlers held their arms up as if they held something in their hands and said: "These are the trousers!"
joy	"This is the coat!" and "Here is the cloak!" and so on.
joy	"They are all as light as a cobweb, and one must feel as if one had nothing at all upon the body; but that is just the beauty of them."
joy	"Indeed!" said all the courtiers; but they could not see anything, for there was nothing to be seen.
joy	"How well they look!
joy	How well they fit!" said all.
joy	"What a beautiful pattern!
joy	What fine colours!
joy	That is a magnificent suit of clothes!"
joy	"Does not my suit fit me marvellously?"
fear	The chamberlains, who were to carry the train, stretched their hands to the ground as if they lifted up a train, and pretended to hold something in their hands; they did not like people to know that they could not see anything.
surprise	The emperor marched in the procession under the beautiful canopy, and all who saw him in the street and out of the windows exclaimed: "Indeed, the emperor's new suit is incomparable!
joy	What a long train he has!
joy	How well it fits him!"
disgust	"But he has nothing on at all," said a little child at last.
sadness	Waldemar Daa remained for a time silent and thoughtful.
sadness	His daughters wept; all the people in the mansion wiped their eyes, but Lady Daa had driven away, and I drove away too," said the Wind.
sadness	Far in the interior of the wood, where a noisy swarm of laborers were working, stood Waldemar Daa and his three daughters, and all were laughing at the wild cries of the birds, excepting one, the youngest, Anna Dorothea, who felt grieved to the heart; and when they made preparations to fell a tree that was almost dead, and on whose naked branches the black stork had built her nest, she saw the poor little things stretching out their necks, and she begged for mercy for them, with the tears in her eyes.
disgust	"'Leave it alone,' I sang down the chimney; 'leave it alone, it will all end in smoke, air, coals, and ashes, and you will burn your fingers.'
disgust	But Waldemar Daa did not leave it alone, and all he possessed vanished like smoke blown by me.
joy	The master of the castle had watched through the night, in feverish excitement, and had been melting and cooling, distilling and mixing.
sadness	I heard him sighing like a soul in despair; I heard him praying, and I noticed how he held his breath.
surprise	'Look at the alchymic glass,' he cried; 'something glows in the crucible, pure and heavy.'
surprise	He lifted it with a trembling hand, and exclaimed in a voice of agitation, 'Gold! gold!'
joy	He was quite giddy, I could have blown him down," said the Wind; "but I only fanned the glowing coals, and accompanied him through the door to the room where his daughter sat shivering.
joy	'Found! found!
joy	Gold! gold!' he shouted, again holding the glass aloft, that it might flash in the sunshine; but his hand trembled, and the alchymic glass fell from it, clattering to the ground, and brake in a thousand pieces.
sadness	Ida and Anna Dorothea wept bitterly, Joanna stood, pale and proud, biting her lips till the blood came; but what could that avail?
sadness	"'O-h, o-h,' she sighed; for people can sigh like the moaning of the wind among the reeds and rushes.
sadness	'O-h, o-h,' she would say, 'no bell sounded at thy burial, Waldemar Daa.
sadness	I suppose he is under the ground now; and Ida- alas! alas! it is not ended yet; miserable that I am!
sadness	Kind Heaven, grant me that I may die.'
sadness	Her eyes were glazing, and her heart breaking; but so it would have been, even had the sun not shone that morning on Anna Dorothea.
surprise	All passed away, passed away!
joy	The sun was shining, the birds were singing, and the confirmed children sang too, holding each other by the hand, for they had no position yet, and they were all equal in the eyes of God.
surprise	When the others arrived at the willow trees, where the confectioner had put up his stall, they said: "Now we are out here; the bell does not in reality exist- it is only something that people imagine!"
joy	"We must try to find out if it is!"
joy	Therefore they let him go alone; and as he walked on, the solitude of the wood produced a feeling of reverence in his breast; but still he heard the little bell about which the others rejoiced, and sometimes, when the wind blew in that direction, he could hear the sounds from the confectioner's stall, where the others were singing at tea.
joy	"I will and must find the bell," he said, "if I have to go to the end of the world."
joy	"Oh, what a splendour!"
joy	The sea, the great majestic sea, which was rolling its long waves against the shore, stretched out before him, and the sun was standing like a large bright altar and there where sea and heaven met- all melted together in the most glowing colours; the wood was singing, and his heart too.
joy	The whole of nature was one large holy church, in which the trees and hovering clouds formed the pillars, the flowers and grass the woven velvet carpet, and heaven itself was the great cupola; up there the flame colour vanished as soon as the sun disappeared, but millions of stars were lighted; diamond lamps were shining, and the king's son stretched his arms out towards heaven, towards the sea, and towards the wood.
joy	And they ran towards each other and took one another's hand, in the great cathedral of nature and poesy, and above them sounded the invisible holy bell; happy spirits surrounded them, singing hallelujahs and rejoicing.
joy	He knew very well that he had enough inside him to buy up all the other toys, and this gave him a very good opinion of his own value.
joy	Upon this there was a great uproar; even the engravings, which hung in frames on the wall, turned round in their excitement, and showed that they had a wrong side to them, although they had not the least intention to expose themselves in this way, or to object to the game.
joy	And as the game was now to begin, all were invited to take part in it, even the children's wagon, which certainly belonged to the coarser playthings.
fear	He stood so high that they were afraid he would not accept a verbal message.
joy	"I crack for everybody," said the cracker.
joy	"Yes, and a fine noise you make," thought the audience, as the play went on.
joy	The doll, whose neck had been darned, was so excited that the place in her neck burst, and the money-pig declared he must do something for one of the players, as they had all pleased him so much.
joy	They all enjoyed the comedy so much, that they gave up all thoughts of the tea party, and only carried out their idea of intellectual amusement, which they called playing at men and women; and there was nothing wrong about it, for it was only play.
surprise	Certainly sooner than he expected- for all at once down he came from the top of the press, fell on the ground, and was broken to pieces.
sadness	She plucks the withered leaf from the balsam, and looks at the grass-covered rampart, on which many children are playing.
sadness	What is the old maid thinking of?
joy	"The poor little children, how happy they are- how merrily they play and romp together!
sadness	What red cheeks and what angels' eyes! but they have no shoes nor stockings.
fear	They dance on the green rampart, just on the place where, according to the old story, the ground always sank in, and where a sportive, frolicsome child had been lured by means of flowers, toys and sweetmeats into an open grave ready dug for it, and which was afterwards closed over the child; and from that moment, the old story says, the ground gave way no longer, the mound remained firm and fast, and was quickly covered with the green turf.
joy	The little people who now play on that spot know nothing of the old tale, else would they fancy they heard a child crying deep below the earth, and the dewdrops on each blade of grass would be to them tears of woe.
sadness	Nor do they know anything of the Danish King who here, in the face of the coming foe, took an oath before all his trembling courtiers that he would hold out with the citizens of his capital, and die here in his nest; they know nothing of the men who have fought here, or of the women who from here have drenched with boiling water the enemy, clad in white, and 'biding in the snow to surprise the city.
sadness	"No! the poor little ones are playing with light, childish spirits.
sadness	Play on, play on, thou little maiden!
fear	Soon the years will come- yes, those glorious years.
sadness	The priestly hands have been laid on the candidates for confirmation; hand in hand they walk on the green rampart.
sadness	Thou hast a white frock on; it has cost thy mother much labor, and yet it is only cut down for thee out of an old larger dress!
anger	You will also wear a red shawl; and what if it hang too far down?
sadness	People will only see how large, how very large it is.
joy	You are thinking of your dress, and of the Giver of all good- so glorious is it to wander on the green rampart!
joy	"And the years roll by; they have no lack of dark days, but you have your cheerful young spirit, and you have gained a friend- you know not how.
surprise	You met, oh, how often!
joy	You walk together on the rampart in the fresh spring, on the high days and holidays, when all the world come out to walk upon the ramparts, and all the bells of the church steeples seem to be singing a song of praise for the coming spring.
sadness	Alas!
sadness	It is not so with the human heart!
sadness	Dark mists, more in number than those that cover the northern skies, cloud the human heart.
sadness	Poor child! thy friend's bridal chamber is a black coffin, and thou becomest an old maid.
sadness	From the almshouse window, behind the balsams, thou shalt look on the merry children at play, and shalt see thine own history renewed."
sadness	And that is the life drama that passes before the old maid while she looks out upon the rampart, the green, sunny rampart, where the children, with their red cheeks and bare shoeless feet, are rejoicing merrily, like the other free little birds.
anger	But inside the church the pastor stood in the pulpit, and spoke very loudly and angrily.
anger	He said that all men were wicked, and God would punish them for their sins, and that the wicked, when they died, would be cast into hell, to burn for ever and ever.
anger	He spoke very excitedly, saying that their evil propensities would not be destroyed, nor would the fire be extinguished, and they should never find rest.
fear	It was dreadful to hear all that, for the preacher spoke from his heart, and all the people in the church were terrified.
joy	Meanwhile, the birds sang merrily outside, and the sun was shining so beautifully warm, it seemed as though every little flower said: "God, Thy kindness towards us all is without limits."
sadness	The same evening, upon going to bed, the pastor noticed his wife sitting there quiet and pensive.
fear	Alas! eternally- how long!
surprise	No, I am unable to imagine that, although you say so."
sadness	She was buried; two large tears rolled over the cheeks of the earnest man, and in the parsonage it was empty and still, for its sun had set for ever.
sadness	She fixed her eyes upon him with such a kind and sad expression, just as if she wished to say something to him.
surprise	The pastor raised himself in bed and stretched his arms towards her, saying, "Not even you can find eternal rest!
surprise	You suffer, you best and most pious woman?"
surprise	"And can I not obtain rest in the grave for you?"
surprise	"Yes, therein, as I believed, as I knew it," said the pastor, "are living those who are abandoned to the eternal fire."
surprise	"He is but a poor fool, and not doomed to be tortured eternally by fire!"
surprise	"Only a fool!"
surprise	"He is ill!
surprise	That is madness- a joyless madness- besieged by fear and dreadful dreams!"
anger	Like a ferocious animal, one of them rose out of his sleep and uttered a horrible cry, and gave his comrade a violent dig in the ribs with his pointed elbow, and this one turned round in his sleep: "Be quiet, monster- sleep!
anger	This happens every night!"
anger	"Every night!" repeated the other.
anger	"Yes, every night he comes and tortures me!
sadness	I myself helped to rescue cattle and things, nothing alive burnt, except a flight of pigeons, which flew into the fire, and the yard dog, of which I had not thought; one could hear him howl out of the fire, and this howling I still hear when I wish to sleep; and when I have fallen asleep, the great rough dog comes and places himself upon me, and howls, presses, and tortures me.
anger	You can snore; you are snoring the whole night, and I hardly a quarter of an hour!"
anger	And the blood rose to the head of the excited criminal; he threw himself upon his comrade, and beat him with his clenced fist in the face.
fear	The pastor's hand trembled; he dared not stretch it out, he did not venture to pull a hair out of the sinner's head.
fear	"Father of all mercy, grant Thou to her the peace that I was unable to procure for her!"
joy	"I have it now!" said the dead woman.
sadness	"WHENEVER a good child dies, an angel of God comes down from heaven, takes the dead child in his arms, spreads out his great white wings, and flies with him over all the places which the child had loved during his life.
joy	Then he gathers a large handful of flowers, which he carries up to the Almighty, that they may bloom more brightly in heaven than they do on earth.
joy	And the Almighty presses the flowers to His heart, but He kisses the flower that pleases Him best, and it receives a voice, and is able to join the song of the chorus of bliss."
joy	Then they passed over well-known spots, where the little one had often played, and through beautiful gardens full of lovely flowers.
joy	"Which of these shall we take with us to heaven to be transplanted there?" asked the angel.
sadness	Close by grew a slender, beautiful, rose-bush, but some wicked hand had broken the stem, and the half-opened rosebuds hung faded and withered on the trailing branches.
sadness	"Poor rose-bush!" said the child, "let us take it with us to heaven, that it may bloom above in God's garden."
joy	The angel took up the rose-bush; then he kissed the child, and the little one half opened his eyes.
joy	The angel gathered also some beautiful flowers, as well as a few humble buttercups and heart's-ease.
joy	"Now we have flowers enough," said the child; but the angel only nodded, he did not fly upward to heaven.
fear	It was night, and quite still in the great town.
sadness	Amidst all this confusion, the angel pointed to the pieces of a broken flower-pot, and to a lump of earth which had fallen out of it.
sadness	The earth had been kept from falling to pieces by the roots of a withered field-flower, which had been thrown amongst the rubbish.
joy	"We will take this with us," said the angel, "I will tell you why as we fly along."
sadness	"Down in that narrow lane, in a low cellar, lived a poor sick boy; he had been afflicted from his childhood, and even in his best days he could just manage to walk up and down the room on crutches once or twice, but no more.
sadness	In this spot the poor sick boy would sit warming himself in the sunshine, and watching the red blood through his delicate fingers as he held them before his face.
surprise	Then he would say he had been out, yet he knew nothing of the green forest in its spring verdure, till a neighbor's son brought him a green bough from a beech-tree.
joy	This he would place over his head, and fancy that he was in the beech-wood while the sun shone, and the birds carolled gayly.
surprise	One spring day the neighbor's boy brought him some field-flowers, and among them was one to which the root still adhered.
joy	This he carefully planted in a flower-pot, and placed in a window-seat near his bed.
joy	And the flower had been planted by a fortunate hand, for it grew, put forth fresh shoots, and blossomed every year.
joy	It became a splendid flower-garden to the sick boy, and his little treasure upon earth.
joy	He watered it, and cherished it, and took care it should have the benefit of every sunbeam that found its way into the cellar, from the earliest morning ray to the evening sunset.
joy	The flower entwined itself even in his dreams- for him it bloomed, for him spread its perfume.
joy	And it gladdened his eyes, and to the flower he turned, even in death, when the Lord called him.
sadness	He has been one year with God.
sadness	During that time the flower has stood in the window, withered and forgotten, till at length cast out among the sweepings into the street, on the day of the lodgers' removal.
joy	And this poor flower, withered and faded as it is, we have added to our nosegay, because it gave more real joy than the most beautiful flower in the garden of a queen."
surprise	"But how do you know all this?" asked the child whom the angel was carrying to heaven.
joy	"I know it," said the angel, "because I myself was the poor sick boy who walked upon crutches, and I know my own flower well."
joy	Then the child opened his eyes and looked into the glorious happy face of the angel, and at the same moment they found themselves in that heavenly home where all is happiness and joy.
joy	And God pressed the dead child to His heart, and wings were given him so that he could fly with the angel, hand in hand.
joy	Then the Almighty pressed all the flowers to His heart; but He kissed the withered field-flower, and it received a voice.
joy	Then it joined in the song of the angels, who surrounded the throne, some near, and others in a distant circle, but all equally happy.
joy	They all joined in the chorus of praise, both great and small,- the good, happy child, and the poor field-flower, that once lay withered and cast away on a heap of rubbish in a narrow, dark street.
sadness	Well, perhaps, if in the beginning of a book these were written and printed, many, when they read it, would lay the book down and say, "It seems to me a very miserable title, I don't like things of this sort."
joy	So I have inherited from him, not only my good temper, but a habit of going often to the churchyard, which is good, when done in a proper humor; and then also I take in the Intelligencer, just as he used to do.
joy	I am not very young, I have neither wife nor children, nor a library, but, as I said, I read the Intelligencer, which is enough for me; it is to me a delightful paper, and so it was to my father.
surprise	And then what a number of subscriptions to charities, and what innocent verses!
joy	The newspaper and the churchyard were always exciting objects to me.
sadness	Here, behind the white iron railings, once a rose-tree grew; it is gone now, but a little bit of evergreen, from a neighboring grave, stretches out its green tendrils, and makes some appearance; there rests a very unhappy man, and yet while he lived he might be said to occupy a very good position.
anger	He had enough to live upon, and something to spare; but owing to his refined tastes the least thing in the world annoyed him.
anger	If he went to a theatre of an evening, instead of enjoying himself he would be quite annoyed if the machinist had put too strong a light into one side of the moon, or if the representations of the sky hung over the scenes when they ought to have hung behind them; or if a palm-tree was introduced into a scene representing the Zoological Gardens of Berlin, or a cactus in a view of Tyrol, or a beech-tree in the north of Norway.
surprise	As if these things were of any consequence!
surprise	Why did he not leave them alone?
surprise	Who would trouble themselves about such trifles? especially at a comedy, where every one is expected to be amused.
joy	It is beautiful to observe how wisely nature orders these things.
surprise	Here rests,- ah, it makes one feel mournful to think of him!- but here rests a man who, during sixty-seven years, was never remembered to have said a good thing; he lived only in the hope of having a good idea.
joy	At last he felt convinced, in his own mind, that he really had one, and was so delighted that he positively died of joy at the thought of having at last caught an idea.
surprise	I come here often, and if any of my friends, or those who are not my friends, are too much for me, I go out and choose a plot of ground in which to bury him or her.
surprise	Then I bury them, as it were; there they lie, dead and powerless, till they come back new and better characters.
surprise	Then, if any of our friends act absurdly, no one need to be vexed about it.
joy	Let them bury the offenders out of sight, and keep their good temper.
joy	"The man with a cheerful temper."
sadness	Grandmother says that she has heard her own grandmother tell of him; he is said to lead a solitary life, and to have nobody with whom he can converse save the great old church Bell.
joy	"Ding-dong! ding-dong!" sounded the Bell, when the tower still stood there; and one evening, while the sun was setting, and the Bell was swinging away bravely, it broke loose and came flying down through the air, the brilliant metal shining in the ruddy beam.
joy	"Ding-dong! ding-dong!
joy	Now I'll retire to rest!" sang the Bell, and flew down into the Odense-Au, where it is deepest; and that is why the place is called the "bell-deep."
sadness	But the Bell got neither rest nor sleep.
joy	Down in the Au-mann's haunt it sounds and rings, so that the tones sometimes pierce upward through the waters; and many people maintain that its strains forebode the death of some one; but that is not true, for the Bell is only talking with the Au-mann, who is now no longer alone.
joy	Ding-dong! ding-dong!"
sadness	I may sing of everything that is kept concealed behind lock and bars.
sadness	Yonder it is cold and wet.
fear	The rats are eating her up alive!
sadness	Nobody knows of it!
sadness	Nobody hears of it!
sadness	Not even now, for the bell is ringing and singing its loud Ding-dong, ding-dong!'
fear	He sought shelter in the church, and shut gate and door behind him.
sadness	The throng in front of the church knew where they could hit the King, and one of them flung a stone through a pane of glass, and the King lay there dead!
joy	"The church bell hangs high, and looks far around, and sees the birds around it, and understands their language.
joy	The wind roars in upon it through windows and loopholes; and the wind knows everything, for he gets it from the air, which encircles all things, and the church bell understands his tongue, and rings it out into the world, 'Ding-dong! ding-dong!'
sadness	"But it was too much for me to hear and to know; I was not able any longer to ring it out.
sadness	I became so tired, so heavy, that the beam broke, and I flew out into the gleaming Au, where the water is deepest, and where the Au-mann lives, solitary and alone; and year by year I tell him what I have heard and what I know.
sadness	But the schoolmaster says that there was not any bell that rung down there, for that it could not do so; and that no Au-mann dwelt yonder, for there was no Au-mann at all!
fear	"Be cautious, cautious, and take good heed to thyself," they both say.
joy	It is around us, it is in us, it talks of our thoughts and of our deeds, and it speaks longer of them than does the Bell down in the depths of the Odense-Au where the Au-mann dwells.
sadness	The elder one, who was named Care, looked rather gloomy; she always goes about to perform her own business in person; for then she knows it is properly done.

surprise	Oh dear!
surprise	I certainly am very queer."

joy	"Modestia is a beautiful virtue," said the man.

surprise	"Every-day stories?" asked the bachelor.
joy	"Oh," replied the man, with a smile; "and yet they are very witty, and are much read at Court.
surprise	"Goodness me! where am I?" said he.
surprise	It bewildered him as he thought of it.
fear	The counsellor felt a cold shiver run all over him.
