joy	"Yes, this is East Street; how beautifully bright and gay it looks!
joy	He thought of all the terror and anxiety which he had undergone, and felt thankful from his heart for the reality and comfort of modern times, which, with all their errors, were far better than those in which he so lately found himself.
sadness	The riches and the honor came for me; Yet still my greatest wealth was poverty: Ah, help and pity me!
sadness	Thou knowest: ah, pity me!
sadness	The lieutenant felt this very keenly, and therefore leaned his head against the window-frame, and sighed deeply.
sadness	"The poor watchman in the street," said he, "is far happier than I am.
sadness	Oh, how much happier I should be could I change my being and position with him, and pass through life with his humble expectations and hopes!
sadness	Yes, he is indeed happier than I am."
fear	All his comrades were very much frightened, for he seemed quite dead; still they allowed him to remain after they had given notice of what had happened; and at dawn the body was carried to the hospital.
fear	He declared, when he quite recovered himself, that this had been the most dreadful night he had ever passed; not for a hundred pounds would he go through such feelings again.
anger	His first feeling was one of anger, and then his spirits sank below zero.
joy	"What a free, happy man you are.
joy	This is a splendid spring day for a poet, the air is so remarkably clear, the clouds are so beautiful, and the green grass has such a sweet smell.
joy	For many years I have not felt as I do at this moment."
joy	"What a delightful perfume," said he; "it reminds me of the violets at Aunt Lora's.
sadness	Yes, this is my fate," and he sighed deeply.
joy	It is overpowering, and yet it is delightful."
joy	As the clerk thought of all these things, and became conscious of the great change in his own feelings, he smiled, and said to himself, "I must be asleep and dreaming; and yet, if so, how wonderful for a dream to be so natural and real, and to know at the same time too that it is but a dream.
sadness	"Ah!" he sighed mournfully, as he gazed at the birds singing merrily, or hopping from branch to branch, "they are much better off than I. Flying is a glorious power.
joy	He felt what was taking place, and laughed to himself.
joy	"Well," thought he, "this is charming; by day I sit in a police-office, amongst the dryest law papers, and at night I can dream that I am a lark, flying about in the gardens of Fredericksburg.
sadness	It is a miserable story indeed, especially now I have fallen into the hands of boys.
anger	The boys carried him into a very elegant room, where a stout, pleasant-looking lady received them, but she was not at all gratified to find that they had brought a lark- a common field-bird as she called it.
joy	"It will please Polly perhaps," she said, laughing at a large gray parrot, who was swinging himself proudly on a ring in a handsome brass cage.
joy	Ha! ha! ha!" laughed Polly, and repeated his witty saying, "Now let us be men."
fear	The canary-bird fluttered in his cage, and the parrot flapped his wings and cried, "Let us be men;" the poor clerk, in the most deadly terror, flew through the window, over the houses, and through the streets, till at length he was obliged to seek a resting-place.
joy	"Oh, to travel, to travel!" cried he; "there is no greater happiness in the world: it is the height of my ambition.
sadness	"Ah," he sighed, "if I were only on the other side of the Alps now, it would be summer, and I should be able to get money on my letter of credit.
sadness	Oh, I wish I was on the other side of the Alps."
sadness	It was a glorious spectacle; but the stomachs of the travellers were empty, their bodies exhausted with fatigue, and all the longings of their heart turned towards a resting-place for the night; but where to find one they knew not.
sadness	All the eyes were too eagerly seeking for this resting-place, to notice the beauties of nature.
joy	THERE was once a butterfly who wished for a bride, and, as may be supposed, he wanted to choose a very pretty one from among the flowers.
joy	The butterfly came also to Marguerite to inquire, but he did not pluck off her leaves; he pressed a kiss on each of them, for he thought there was always more to be done by kindness.
anger	But Marguerite did not answer him; she was offended that he should call her a woman when she was only a girl; and there is a great difference.
joy	"They are very pretty," thought the butterfly; "charming little lasses; but they are rather formal."
sadness	The violet, a little too sentimental.
joy	The pea-blossom pleased him most of all; she was white and red, graceful and slender, and belonged to those domestic maidens who have a pretty appearance, and can yet be useful in the kitchen.
joy	You know, this plant has no blossom; but it is sweetness all over,- full of fragrance from head to foot, with the scent of a flower in every leaf.
joy	"I will take her," said the butterfly; and he made her an offer.
joy	He could exist here, he said, well enough.
sadness	"But it is not enough merely to exist," said he, "I need freedom, sunshine, and a little flower for a companion."
joy	Then he flew against the window-pane, and was seen and admired by those in the room, who caught him, and stuck him on a pin, in a box of curiosities.
sadness	"It is not very pleasant, certainly; I should imagine it is something like being married; for here I am stuck fast."
sadness	"That seems very poor consolation," said one of the plants in the room, that grew in a pot.
joy	"Look at me," said the top to the ball.
joy	No one could be happier than we should be."
joy	Every time I fly up in the air, he puts his head out of the nest, and says, 'Will you?' and I have said, 'Yes,' to myself silently, and that is as good as being half engaged; but I will promise never to forget you."
anger	"Much good that will be to me," said the top; and they spoke to each other no more.
sadness	The boy searched everywhere for it, but he searched in vain, for it could not be found; it was gone.
sadness	"I know very well where she is," sighed the top; "she is in the swallow's nest, and has married the swallow."
sadness	The more the top thought of this, the more he longed for the ball.
joy	"Now I am in a nice place," said he; "my gilding will soon be washed off here.
sadness	The sisters mourned as young hearts can mourn, and were especially grieved at the sight of their parents' sorrow.
sadness	The father's heart was bowed down, but the mother sunk completely under the deep grief.
sadness	She thought God could not take her darling little one from her; and when it did happen notwithstanding her hopes and her belief, and there could be no more doubt on the subject, she said in her feverish agony, "God does not know it.
sadness	Thus in her great grief she fell away from her faith in God, and dark thoughts arose in her mind respecting death and a future state.
sadness	But these doubts were no support to her, nothing on which she could rest, and she sunk into the fathomless depths of despair.
sadness	In her darkest hours she ceased to weep, and thought not of the young daughters who were still left to her.
sadness	The tears of her husband fell on her forehead, but she took no notice of him; her thoughts were with her dead child; her whole existence seemed wrapped up in the remembrances of the little one and of every innocent word it had uttered.
sadness	When she awoke, and wanted to see her child, the husband, with tears, said, "We have closed the coffin; it was necessary to do so."
sadness	"When God is so hard to me, how can I expect men to be better?" she said with groans and tears.
sadness	She gave herself up to her grief, and it tossed her to and fro, as the sea tosses a ship without compass or rudder.
sadness	With tearful eyes and mournful glances, the sorrowing daughters and the afflicted husband looked upon her who would not hear their words of comfort; and, indeed, what comforting words could they speak, when they were themselves so full of grief?
sadness	As she had sat by his little cot, so now she sat by his grave; and here she could weep freely, and her tears fell upon it.
sadness	"Down to my child," she repeated; and tones of despair and entreaty sounded in the words.
joy	"My sweet, darling mother," she heard the child say.
joy	It was the well-known, beloved voice; and kiss followed kiss, in boundless delight.
joy	"There is nothing so beautiful on earth as it is here.
joy	Oh, it is happiness indeed."
joy	"I can fly now, mother," said the child; "I can fly with other happy children into the presence of the Almighty.
sadness	"Oh, stay, stay!" implored the mother; "only one moment more; only once more, that I may look upon thee, and kiss thee, and press thee to my heart."
fear	And then she remembered those she left behind, and a great terror came over her.
sadness	No; their sighs and lamentations still sounded from above; and she had nearly forgotten them, for the sake of him who was dead.
joy	And when she had offered this prayer, her heart felt lighter.
joy	Everything around her seemed holy, and her heart was chastened.
joy	She bent over her husband, who still slept; her warm, devoted kiss awakened him, and words of heartfelt love fell from the lips of both.
joy	Now she was gentle and strong as a wife can be; and from her lips came the words of faith: "Whatever He doeth is right and best."
joy	And as she kissed him and her children, she said, "It came from God, through my child in the grave."
joy	"I obtained the first prize," said the hare.
joy	"I should imagine no one can be swifter in soaring and flight than I am; and how far I have been! far, far away."
anger	"I deserved the first prize, and not the second," said the snail.
anger	"What a buzzing and a rumbling there is in the elfin hill," said one of the lizards; "I have not been able to close my eyes for two nights on account of the noise; I might just as well have had the toothache, for that always keeps me awake."

fear	Then she became terrified, and turned back and repented right heartily of her sin.
sadness	On the following Sunday they all went to church, and she was asked whether she wished to go too; but, with tears in her eyes, she looked sadly at her crutches.
sadness	Here she sat down with her hymn-book, and as she was reading it with a pious mind, the wind carried the notes of the organ over to her from the church, and in tears she lifted up her face and said: "O God! help me!"
sadness	The old grandfather wiped his eyes, for he had known King Frederick, with his silvery locks and his honest blue eyes, and had lived for him, and he folded his hands and remained for some time silent.
sadness	I still remember his face, but from whence he came, or whither he went, I know not; no one knows.
anger	"Thou child of perdition, I will yet carry out my purpose!" cried the Bishop of Borglum.

anger	"Thou Borglum bishop," he exclaims, "I shall subdue thee after all!
anger	Under the shield of the Pope, the law cannot reach thee; but Jens Glob shall reach thee!"
anger	"It is stupid nonsense to allow yourself to shoot out in this way; we are not here to support you."
sadness	Not long after, the king of the country suffered from the deepest melancholy.
sadness	They read deep and learned books to him, and then the lightest and most trifling that could be found, but all to no purpose.
fear	Then said the swineherd, "I am afraid I carried this plant away from the forest in my bundle, and it has been burnt to ashes long ago.
fear	But I did not know any better."
anger	Ignorance upon ignorance indeed!"
sadness	The poor swineherd took these words to heart, for they were addressed to him; he knew not that there were others who were equally ignorant.
sadness	Then the king, in his melancholy, wandered out to the spot in the wood.
sadness	For the plant had disappeared, and the king remained as melancholy and sad as ever, but the sentry said he had always been so.
fear	And again little Tuk lay in his bed, scarcely knowing whether he was dreaming or not, for some one stood by him.
sadness	In the cold and the darkness, a poor little girl, with bare head and naked feet, roamed through the streets.
sadness	No one had bought anything of her the whole day, nor had any one given here even a penny.
sadness	Shivering with cold and hunger, she crept along; poor little child, she looked the picture of misery.
sadness	In a corner, between two houses, one of which projected beyond the other, she sank down and huddled herself together.
fear	She had drawn her little feet under her, but she could not keep off the cold; and she dared not go home, for she had sold no matches, and could not take home even a penny of money.
fear	Her father would certainly beat her; besides, it was almost as cold at home as here, for they had only the roof to cover them, through which the wind howled, although the largest holes had been stopped up with straw and rags.
sadness	Then the match went out, and there remained nothing but the thick, damp, cold wall before her.
sadness	"Some one is dying," thought the little girl, for her old grandmother, the only one who had ever loved her, and who was now dead, had told her that when a star falls, a soul was going up to God.
sadness	"Grandmother," cried the little one, "O take me with you; I know you will go away when the match burns out; you will vanish like the warm stove, the roast goose, and the large, glorious Christmas-tree."
anger	But the tulips stood more stiffly than ever, their faces were pointed and red, because they were vexed.
sadness	The peonies were sulky; it was well that they could not speak, otherwise they would have given the daisy a good lecture.
sadness	The little flower could very well see that they were ill at ease, and pitied them sincerely.
sadness	Indeed the poor bird had good reason to be sad, for it had been caught and put into a cage close by the open window.
sadness	The poor lark was most unhappy as a prisoner in a cage.
fear	"Pluck the flower off" said the other boy, and the daisy trembled for fear, for to be pulled off meant death to it; and it wished so much to live, as it was to go with the square of turf into the poor captive lark's cage.
sadness	The poor bird was lamenting its lost liberty, and beating its wings against the wires; and the little daisy could not speak or utter a consoling word, much as it would have liked to do so.
sadness	"I have no water," said the captive lark, "they have all gone out, and forgotten to give me anything to drink.
sadness	My throat is dry and burning.
sadness	I feel as if I had fire and ice within me, and the air is so oppressive.

sadness	The flower could not, as on the previous evening, fold up its petals and sleep; it dropped sorrowfully.
